(e) Expenditure Charged on the Fund: Declaring specific expenditures as charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (like certain government expenses) or increasing such expenditures.
(f) Receipt and Audit of Money: The receipt, custody, or issue of government funds, and the auditing of accounts for the Union or any State.
(g) Any matter incidental to the above points.
Clause 2: What Is Not a Money Bill?
A Bill will not be considered a Money Bill if it deals with:

Imposing fines or penalties.
Charging fees for licenses or services.
Tax-related matters for local authorities (like municipal taxes) or for local purposes (as opposed to national taxes).
Clause 3: Dispute Over Whether a Bill is a Money Bill
If there is a dispute or confusion about whether a Bill is a Money Bill, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha will make the final decision.
The Speaker's decision is final and cannot be challenged.
Clause 4: Certification of a Money Bill
Every Money Bill must be certified by the Speaker of the Lok Sabha when it is transmitted to the Rajya Sabha and when it is presented to the President for assent.
The Speaker’s certificate verifies that the Bill is indeed a Money Bill.

Article: 111. Assent to Bills When a Bill has been passed by the Houses of Parliament, it shall be presented to the President, and the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill, or that he withholds assent therefrom Provided that the President may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of a Bill for assent, return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill to the Houses with a message requesting that they will reconsider the Bill or any specified provisions thereof and, in particular, will consider the desirability of introducing any such amendments as he may recommend in his message, and when a Bill is so returned, the Houses shall reconsider the Bill accordingly, and if the Bill is passed again by the Houses with or without amendment and presented to the President for assent, the President shall not withhold assent therefrom Procedures in Financial Matters
Title: Article 111 - Assent to Bills
Description:
After a bill is passed by both Houses of Parliament, it is sent to the President for approval (assent).
The President can either:
Approve the bill (assent).
Reject the bill (withhold assent).
Return the bill (except in case of money bills) for reconsideration by Parliament.
If Parliament passes the bill again after reconsideration, the President must give assent.

Article 112: Annual Financial Statement
This article explains how the Annual Financial Statement is prepared and presented by the President of India in Parliament, which is essentially the Budget of the Government of India. It outlines the estimated income and expenses for the upcoming financial year.

Clause 1: Presentation of the Annual Financial Statement
The President has to present a statement each year to both Houses of Parliament (the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha) showing the estimated receipts (income) and expenditure (spending) of the Government of India for the upcoming financial year.
This statement is referred to as the "Annual Financial Statement" (the Budget).
Clause 2: Breakdown of the Expenditure
The statement will show the estimated expenditure in two categories:
(a) Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India: This is a special category of expenditure that is automatically paid from the government's main account (Consolidated Fund) without needing Parliament’s approval each year.
(b) Other expenditure: This is the regular expenditure that requires Parliament’s approval.
Additionally, the statement must clearly show:
Expenditure on revenue account: This is for the day-to-day running of the government.
Other types of expenditure: This includes things like investments or capital expenses.
Clause 3: Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund of India
Some expenditures are automatically paid from the Consolidated Fund of India and do not require annual approval from Parliament. These include:

(a) The President's emoluments: The salary, allowances, and office expenses related to the President's office.
(b) The salaries and allowances of key Parliament figures: This includes the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States (Rajya Sabha), the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha.
(c) Debt Charges: These are payments the government makes to cover interest, sinking fund charges, and redemption of loans the government has taken.
(d) Salaries, allowances, and pensions of Judges:
Supreme Court Judges.
Federal Court Judges (for those who served before India became a Republic).
High Court Judges (for those who were serving before the Constitution came into effect).
(e) Salaries and pensions of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG).
(f) Payments to settle court judgments: If the government is required to pay a judgment or award given by a court or arbitral tribunal, that amount is also charged to the Consolidated Fund.
(g) Other expenditure: Any other types of expenditure that are either mentioned in the Constitution or have been designated by Parliament as being charged on the Consolidated Fund.

Article:
113. Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates
 (1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India shall not be submitted to the vote of Parliament, but nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in either House of Parliament of any of those estimates
 (2) So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants to the House of the People, and the House of the People shall have power to assent, or to refuse to assent, to any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein
 (3) No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the President
Title: Article 113: Procedure in Parliament with Respect to Estimates
Description:
Article 113 of the Indian Constitution outlines the process for approving government expenditure and the procedure that Parliament follows with respect to the estimates of expenditure presented in the Annual Financial Statement (the Union Budget).

Clause 1: Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund of India
The estimates for expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (such as debt charges, salaries of the President, salaries of judges, etc.) are not voted on by Parliament.
However, discussion on these estimates is allowed in both Houses of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha).
In simple terms, while Parliament cannot vote to approve or reject these charges (as they are automatically paid), debate on them is still permitted.
Clause 2: Other Expenditure
The estimates for other expenditure (expenses that are not automatically charged on the Consolidated Fund) are presented as demands for grants to the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
Demands for grants refer to the specific requests made by the government for funding particular projects or activities.
The Lok Sabha has the power to:
Approve the demand for the full amount.
Reject the demand entirely.
Approve the demand but with a reduction in the amount requested.
This gives the Lok Sabha significant control over the allocation of funds for government programs.
Clause 3: Presidential Recommendation for Grants
A demand for a grant (a request for funds) cannot be made unless it is recommended by the President.
This ensures that the President has formal approval over the government’s request for funding before Parliament considers it.

Article:
114. Appropriation Bills
 (1) As soon as may be after the grants under article 113 have been made by the House of the People, there shall be introduced a Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India of all moneys required to meet
 (a) the grants so made by the House of the People; and
 (b) the expenditure charged on the Consolidated fund of India but not exceeding in any case the amount shown in the statement previously laid before Parliament
 (2) No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in either House of Parliament which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made or of varying the amount of any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India, and the decision of the person presiding as to whether an amendment is inadmissible under this clause shall be final
 (3) Subject to the provisions of articles 115 and 116, no money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India expect under appropriation made by law passed in accordance with the provisions of this article
Title: Article 114: Appropriation Bills
Description:
Article 114 of the Indian Constitution deals with the Appropriation Bill, which is a legal requirement for the government to access funds from the Consolidated Fund of India. It ensures that money can only be withdrawn for government spending if it is legally authorized through an appropriation process.

Clause 1: Introduction of the Appropriation Bill
Once grants (approved by the Lok Sabha, as per Article 113) are made, the Appropriation Bill is introduced. This Bill authorizes the government to withdraw money from the Consolidated Fund of India.
The purpose of the Bill is to:
Appropriate the grants already approved by the Lok Sabha (for specific projects or spending).
Appropriate the expenditure that is automatically charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (such as debt repayment or judicial salaries), but within the limits already set in the Annual Financial Statement (the Budget).
Example: If the Lok Sabha has approved a grant for education, the Appropriation Bill ensures that the money can be withdrawn from the fund to fulfill this purpose.
Clause 2: Restrictions on Amendments to the Bill
When the Appropriation Bill is discussed in Parliament, no amendments can be made that:
Increase or decrease the amount of the grants already approved.
Change the purpose (destination) of any approved grants or expenditure.
The Presiding officer (Speaker of the Lok Sabha or Chairman of the Rajya Sabha) will decide if any proposed amendment violates this rule. Their decision is final.
Clause 3: Legal Requirement for Withdrawal of Funds
No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India unless it is appropriated by law passed through the Appropriation Bill.
This ensures that government spending is legally authorized and that Parliament has the final say on how funds are spent.

Article:
115. Supplementary, additional or excess grants
 (1) The President shall
 (a) If the amount authorised by any law made in accordance with the provisions of article 114 to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is found to be insufficient for the purposes of that year or when a need has arisenduring the current financial year for supplementary or additional expenditure upon some new service not contemplated in the annual financial statement for that year, or
 (b) if any money has been spent on any service during a financial year in excess of the amount granted for that service and for that year, cause to be laid before both the Houses of Parliament another statement showing the estimated amount of that expenditure or cause to be presented to the House of the People a demand for such excess, as the case may be
 (2) The provisions of articles 112, 113 and 114 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure or demand and also to any law to be made authorising the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or the grant in respect of such demand as they have effect in relation to the annual financial statement and the expenditure mentioned therein or to a demand for a grant and the law to be made for the authorisation of appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or grant
Title: Article 115 - Supplementary, Additional, or Excess Grants
Description:
If the government needs more funds than initially allocated in the Budget, it can ask Parliament for Supplementary Grants to cover the extra expenses.
Article 115: Supplementary, Additional, or Excess Grants
Article 115 of the Indian Constitution provides a process for the government to request additional funds during the financial year if the initial allocation is insufficient or if extra expenses arise. It ensures that Parliament has control over how the government's budget is adjusted.

Clause 1: Circumstances for Additional Grants
The President, if the following situations arise, will submit a request to Parliament for supplementary, additional, or excess grants:

(a) If the funds authorized for a particular service (as per the Appropriation Bill) are found to be insufficient for the current financial year.
For example, if a project faces unforeseen costs or the government needs extra funds for a service, such as healthcare during a pandemic.
(b) If the government spends more than the approved budget on a service during the year.
For instance, if the government has already exceeded the initially allocated funds for a department, it will need extra authorization from Parliament to cover the excess expenditure.
In either case, the President will:

Lay before Parliament a statement showing the additional amount of expenditure required.
Alternatively, a demand will be made in the Lok Sabha for the excess amount that has been spent.
Clause 2: Procedural Application
The process for obtaining these supplementary, additional, or excess grants follows the same procedures as the Annual Financial Statement (Article 112), Demands for Grants (Article 113), and the Appropriation Bill (Article 114).
This means that Parliament will review and approve the additional expenditure just as it would the regular budget.
The process involves:
Discussing and approving the extra funds.
Introducing a law for the appropriation (withdrawal) of funds from the Consolidated Fund of India to meet the new expenditure.

Title: Article 116: Votes on Account, Votes of Credit, and Exceptional Grants
Description:
This article addresses the need for the government to make advance or emergency funding requests in situations where regular budget approval processes cannot be completed on time. It allows the government to access funds when there are urgent or unforeseen expenses.

Clause 1: Powers of the House of the People
The House of the People (Lok Sabha) is empowered to make certain kinds of grants in specific situations, even before the formal approval processes (as outlined in Articles 113 and 114) are completed:

Grant in Advance (Votes on Account)

The House can approve a temporary grant for part of a financial year while the full budget approval process is still pending.
This ensures that essential government functions can continue smoothly without waiting for the full passage of the budget.
Example: If the new budget is delayed but the government needs funds for ongoing services like salaries or infrastructure, the House can approve a vote on account to meet these needs.
Grant for Unexpected Demand (Votes of Credit)

In cases where there is an unexpected financial emergency, such as a natural disaster or a national security crisis, the House can approve funds even if the exact details of the expenditure are unclear or too large to fit within the normal budget process.
Example: If a sudden, large-scale natural disaster requires immediate relief, the House may approve an emergency fund (votes of credit) without needing detailed breakdowns.
Exceptional Grant

The House can approve a one-time exceptional grant that is not part of the regular, recurring expenses of the government for that financial year.
Example: A special grant for a major infrastructure project or an unforeseen expenditure that does not fit into the annual budget.
In each of these cases, Parliament is authorized to make laws for the withdrawal of money from the Consolidated Fund of India to cover these grants.

Clause 2: Procedure for Making Grants
Even though these grants are made under exceptional circumstances, the provisions of Articles 113 and 114 (which outline the procedure for voting on grants and appropriating funds) still apply. This means:

The grants must be reviewed, debated, and passed by the House.
Laws to authorize the appropriation of money from the Consolidated Fund of India must be made according to the procedures outlined in the Constitution, ensuring proper checks and balances.

Article:
117. Special provisions as to financial Bills
 (1) A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub clauses (a) to (f) of clause ( 1 ) of article 110 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the President and a Bill making such provision shall not be introduced in the Council of States: Provided that no recommendation shall be required under this clause for the moving of an amendment making provision for the reduction or abolition of any tax
 (2) A Bill or amendment shall not be deemed to make provision for any of the matters aforesaid by reason only that it provides for the imposition of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment of fees for licences or fees for services rendered, or by reason that it provides for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax by any local authority or body for local purposes
 (3) A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the consolidated Fund of India shall not be passed by either House of Parliament unless the President has recommended to that House the consideration of the Bill Procedure Generally
Title: Article 117 - Special Provisions as to Financial Bills
Description:
Money Bills (those related to taxes, loans, and expenditure) can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha (Lower House) with the President's recommendation.
Article 117: Special Provisions as to Financial Bills
This article lays down specific rules for financial bills in the Indian Parliament, particularly with regard to the approval of expenditures from the Consolidated Fund of India and the recommendation of the President.

Clause 1: Restrictions on the Introduction of Certain Financial Bills
Presidential Recommendation Required

A financial bill (or an amendment to a bill) that deals with matters listed in Article 110, Clause 1(a) to (f) (related to the imposition, regulation, and spending of taxes, or borrowing of money) cannot be introduced or moved in Parliament without the recommendation of the President.
This ensures that financial matters, particularly those that directly impact government revenue and expenditure, are introduced with the President's prior approval, which represents the executive branch’s consent.
A financial bill with such provisions cannot be introduced in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) either. It must start in the House of the People (Lok Sabha).
Exceptions for Certain Amendments

The clause makes an exception: No Presidential recommendation is needed for moving an amendment to a bill if the amendment reduces or abolishes a tax. This allows Parliament to discuss and pass amendments that aim to reduce taxes without needing prior approval from the President.
Clause 2: What Does Not Count as a Financial Bill
A bill or amendment that introduces provisions for penalties, fines, fees for licenses, or taxes imposed by local authorities (for local purposes) does not count as a financial bill, even if it touches on taxes or fees.
Essentially, the clause clarifies that local taxes or fees for services (e.g., licensing fees) imposed by local authorities do not make a bill subject to the special provisions for financial bills, meaning these bills can proceed with fewer restrictions.
Clause 3: Recommendation for Bills Involving Expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India
If a bill involves expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India (i.e., it requires the government to spend money from the central fund), it cannot be passed by either House of Parliament unless the President has recommended the consideration of the bill.
This ensures that any spending from the Consolidated Fund is authorized by the executive (the President) before Parliament discusses or approves it.

Article:
118. Rules of procedure
 (1) Each House of Parliament may make rules for regulations, subject to the provisions of this Constitution, its procedure and the conduct of its business
 (2) Until rules are made under clause ( 1 ), the rules of procedure and standing orders in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution with respect to the Legislature of the Dominion of India shall have effect in relation to Parliament subject to such modifications and adaptations as may be made therein by the Chairman of the Council of States or the Speaker of the House of the People, as the case may be
 (3) The President, after consultation with the Chairman of the Council of States and the Speaker of the House of the People, may make rules as to the procedure with respect to joint sittings of, and communications between, the two Houses
 (4) At a joint sitting of the two Houses the Speaker of the House of the People, or in his absence such person as may be determined by rules of procedure made under clause ( 3 ), shall preside
Title: Article 118: Rules of Procedure
Description:
This article gives Parliament the authority to make its own rules regarding how it conducts its business, regulates its procedures, and handles joint sittings between the two Houses. It also lays down specific provisions regarding the rules for joint sittings and the presiding officer at such sittings.

Clause 1: Rules for Procedure and Conduct of Business
Each House of Parliament (i.e., the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha) has the power to make its own rules for the procedure and conduct of its business, as long as these rules do not contradict the Constitution.
These rules can cover the organization of debates, voting procedures, motions, questioning, and other aspects of parliamentary functioning.
Clause 2: Interim Rules
Interim rules: If a House has not yet made its own rules, the rules and standing orders that were in force immediately before the Constitution came into effect (during the time of the Dominion of India) will still apply. However, these can be modified or adapted by:
The Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States), or
The Speaker of the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
This clause ensures that there is no vacuum in the parliamentary procedures during the transition period, and business can still be conducted as per the previous rules.
Clause 3: Rules for Joint Sittings and Communication Between Houses
The President of India has the authority, after consulting both the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and the Speaker of the Lok Sabha, to make rules for joint sittings of the two Houses and for the communication between the Houses.
This is particularly important for matters like joint discussions or voting on issues that require the approval of both Houses together (e.g., in cases where both Houses cannot agree on a Bill, they may meet in a joint session).
The rules would help in coordination and smooth functioning of joint sittings.
Clause 4: Presiding Officer at Joint Sitting
At a joint sitting of the two Houses of Parliament, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha will preside over the session. If the Speaker is absent, then the person who has been designated by the rules of procedure made under clause (3) will preside instead.

Article: 119. Regulation by law of procedure in Parliament in relation to financial business Parliament may, for the purpose of the timely completion of financial business, regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, each House of Parliament in relation to any financial matter or to any Bill for the appropriation of moneys out of the consolidated Fund of India, and, if and so far as any provision of any law so made is inconsistent with any rule made by a House of Parliament under clause ( 1 ) of Article 118 or with any rule or standing order having effect in relation to Parliament under clause ( 2 ) of that article, such provision shall prevail
Title: Article 119 - Regulation by Law of Procedure in Parliament in Relation to Financial Business
Description: Parliament can make laws to regulate the procedures for financial matters, such as the passage of the Budget and financial proposals, ensuring they are handled in a timely manner.

Article:
120. Language to be used in Parliament
 (1) Notwithstanding anything in Part XVII, but subject to the Article 348, business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or in English: Provided that the Chairman of the Council of States or Speaker of the House of the People, or Person acting as such, as the Case may be, may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in Hindi or in English to address the House in his mother tongue
 (2) Unless Parliament by Law otherwise provides, this article shall, after the expiration of a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, have effect as if the words or in English were omitted therefrom
Title: Article 120 - Language to be Used in Parliament
Description:
Business in Parliament can be conducted in Hindi or English.
If a member doesn't know these languages, they can speak in their regional language, as permitted by the Speaker.

Article: 121. Restriction on discussion in Parliament No discussions shall take place in Parliament with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties expect upon a motion for presenting an address to the President praying for the removal of the Judge as hereinafter provided
Title: Article 121 - Restriction on Discussion in Parliament
Description: Parliament cannot discuss the conduct of judges of the Supreme Court or High Courts while they are performing their judicial functions, except in cases where a judge’s removal is being considered.

Article:
122. Courts not to inquire into proceedings of Parliament
 (1) The validity of any proceedings in Parliament shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure
 (2) No officer or member of Parliament in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution for regulating procedure or the conduct of business, or for maintaining order, in Parliament shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers CHAPTER III LEGISLATIVE POWERS OF THE PRESIDENT
Title: Article 122 - Courts Not to Inquire into Proceedings of Parliament
Description:
The courts cannot question or interfere in the proceedings of Parliament, even if the procedure followed by Parliament was irregular.
This ensures Parliament’s autonomy in its internal matters.

Article:
123. Power of President to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Parliament
 (1) If at any time, except when both Houses of Parliament are in session, the President is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinance as the circumstances appear to him to require
 (2) An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of Parliament, but every such Ordinance
 (a) shall be laid before both House of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassemble of Parliament, or, if before the expiration of that period resolutions disapproving it are passed by both Houses, upon the passing of the second of those resolutions; and
 (b) may be withdrawn at any time by the President Explanation Where the Houses of Parliament are summoned to reassemble on different dates, the period of six weeks shall be reckoned from the later of those dates for the purposes of this clause
 (3) If and so far as an Ordinance under this article makes any provision which Parliament would not under this Constitution be competent to enact, it shall be void CHAPTER IV THE UNION JUDICIARY
Title: Article 123: Power of President to Promulgate Ordinances During Recess of Parliament
Description:
This article provides the President of India with the power to issue Ordinances when Parliament is not in session, in cases where immediate action is needed. An Ordinance is a temporary law made by the President, and it has the same effect as an Act of Parliament but with specific limitations.

Clause 1: Conditions for Promulgating an Ordinance
When both Houses of Parliament are not in session, and the President believes that urgent action is required due to certain circumstances, he can promulgate an Ordinance.
This power allows the President to make laws during a recess (when Parliament is not in session) when a delay in legislation could be detrimental or harmful.
The President can take action based on the situation and needs of the moment, even if Parliament is not available to discuss or pass a Bill.
Clause 2: Characteristics of the Ordinance
Force and effect: An Ordinance has the same power and legal effect as an Act of Parliament (a law passed by Parliament).

However, it is not permanent. It will automatically cease to have effect under the following conditions:

Six weeks after Parliament reconvenes, unless Parliament approves it before then.
Resolutions disapproving the Ordinance: If both Houses of Parliament pass resolutions rejecting the Ordinance, it will cease to have effect once the second resolution is passed.
Power to withdraw: The President can also withdraw the Ordinance at any time, even before the six-week period ends.

Explanation: If Parliament is reconvened on different dates, the six-week period is calculated from the later date of the two reconvening dates.

Clause 3: Restrictions on Ordinances
An Ordinance cannot make laws that Parliament would not be competent to enact under the Constitution. If it does, such a provision in the Ordinance will be void (invalid).
For example, if the Ordinance violates any constitutional limitations or exceeds the powers granted to Parliament, it will be considered null and void.

Article:
124. Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court
 (1) There shall be a Supreme Court of India constituting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than seven other Judges
 (2) Every Judge of the Supreme Court shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal after consultation with such of the Judges of the Supreme Court and of the High Courts in the States as the President may deem necessary for the purpose and shall hold office until he attains the age of sixty five years: Provided that in the case of appointment of a Judge other than the chief Justice, the chief Justice of India shall always be consulted:
 (a) a Judge may, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign his office;
 (b) a Judge may be removed rom his office in the manner provided in clause ( 4 )
2A. The age of a Judge of the Supreme Court shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law provide
 (3) A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court unless he is a citizen of India and
 (a) has been for at least five years a Judge of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or
 (b) has been for at least ten years an advocate of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or
 (c) is, in the opinion of the President, a distinguished jurist Explanation I In this clause High Court means a High Court which exercises, or which at any time before the commencement of this Constitution exercised, jurisdiction in any part of the territory of India Explanation II In computing for the purpose of this clause the period during which a person has been an advocate, any period during which a person has held judicial office not inferior to that of a district judge after he became an advocate shall be included
 (4) A Judge of the Supreme Court shall not be removed from his office except by an order of the President passed after an address by each House of Parliament supported by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two third of the members of the House present and voting has been presented to the President in the same session for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity
 (5) Parliament may by law regulate the procedure for the presentation of an address and for the investigation and proof of the misbehaviour or incapacity of a Judge under clause ( 4 ):
 (6) Every person appointed to be a Judge of the Supreme Court shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
 (7) No person who has held office as a Judge of the Supreme Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority within the territory of India
Title: Article 124: Establishment and Constitution of the Supreme Court of India
Description:
This article outlines the establishment, constitution, and appointment procedures for the Supreme Court of India.

Clause 1: Establishment of the Supreme Court
Supreme Court: The highest judicial authority in India, which shall be established by the Constitution.
Composition:
The Chief Justice of India (CJI) is the head of the Supreme Court.
Until Parliament decides to increase the number, the Supreme Court will have no more than seven other judges, aside from the Chief Justice.
Clause 2: Appointment of Judges
The President of India appoints all Judges of the Supreme Court through a formal process.
The President consults with the Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts before making the appointment, to ensure fairness and due process.
A Judge will hold office until the age of 65.
Consultation with CJI: For appointing a judge other than the Chief Justice, the Chief Justice of India must always be consulted.
A judge can resign by writing a resignation letter addressed to the President.
A judge can be removed from office under clause 4.
Clause 2A: Determining the Age of a Judge
Parliament may make a law to determine the age of a Supreme Court Judge through a specified authority and method.
Clause 3: Qualifications for Appointment
A person must meet one of the following criteria to be appointed as a Supreme Court Judge:

Judge of a High Court:

Must have served for at least five years as a judge in a High Court, or served as a judge in two or more High Courts in succession.
Advocate in a High Court:

Must have been an advocate for at least ten years in a High Court, or in two or more High Courts in succession.
Distinguished Jurist:

In the President’s opinion, the person must be a distinguished jurist, someone who has contributed notably to the field of law.
Explanation:

The term High Court includes any High Court that has exercised jurisdiction in any part of India's territory, even before the Constitution came into effect.
If a person has held a judicial office equivalent to that of a district judge after becoming an advocate, this period can be counted as part of the ten years of being an advocate.
Clause 4: Removal of Judges
A Supreme Court Judge cannot be removed from office unless:
An address is presented to the President by both Houses of Parliament.
The address must be supported by a majority of the total membership of each House.
Additionally, two-thirds of the members present and voting in both Houses must support the address.
The removal is based on proved misbehaviour or incapacity.
Clause 5: Regulation of Procedure
Parliament may make a law to regulate:
The procedure for presenting an address to the President for removal.
The procedure for investigating and proving misbehaviour or incapacity of a Judge.
Clause 6: Oath or Affirmation
Before starting their duties, every appointed Supreme Court Judge must take an oath or affirmation before the President or someone appointed by the President.
The oath is according to the form specified in the Third Schedule of the Constitution.
Clause 7: Restrictions After Retirement
A person who has served as a Judge of the Supreme Court cannot plead or act in any court or before any authority within India once they retire. This is to ensure independence and impartiality of the judiciary.

Article:
125. Salaries, etc, of Judges
 (1) There shall be paid to the Judges of the Supreme Court such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries as are specified in the Second Schedule
 (2) Every Judge shall be entitled to such privileges and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament and, until so determined, to such privileges, allowances and rights as are specified in the Second Schedule: Provided that neither the privileges nor the allowances of a Judge nor his rights in respect of leave of absence or pension shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment
Title: Article 125 - Salaries, etc, of Judges
Description:
This article talks about the salaries and benefits of judges in the Supreme Court.

The government will pay judges a salary, which is decided by Parliament.
The judges will also get certain privileges, allowances, and benefits like leave and pension, which Parliament decides.
Once a judge is appointed, their benefits can’t be reduced. They cannot lose any privileges after becoming a judge.

Article: 126. Appointment of acting Chief Justice When the office of Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is, by reason or absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office, the duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose
Title: Article 126 - Appointment of Acting Chief Justice
Description: When the Chief Justice of India is not available (maybe because they’re absent or the position is vacant), the President can appoint another judge from the Supreme Court to do the Chief Justice’s job temporarily.

Article:
127. Appointment of ad hoc Judges
 (1) If at any time there should not be a quorum of the Judges of the Supreme Court available to hold or continue any session of the Court, the Chief Justice of India may, with the previous consent of the President and after consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court concerned, request in writing the attendance at the sittings of the Court, as an ad hoc Judge, for such period as may be necessary, of a Judge of a High Court duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court to be designated by the Chief Justice of India
 (2) It shall be the duty of the Judge who has been so designated, in priority to other duties of his office, to attend the sittings of the Supreme Court at the time and for the period for which his attendance is required, and while so attending he shall have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges, and shall discharge the duties, of a Judge of the Supreme Court
Title: Article 127 - Appointment of ad hoc Judges
Description:
Sometimes, there may not be enough judges in the Supreme Court to continue a case.

In such situations, the Chief Justice can ask a judge from a High Court (who qualifies to be a Supreme Court judge) to temporarily join the Supreme Court as an ad hoc judge to help out.
The judge will prioritize this job and have the same powers as any other Supreme Court judge while doing this work.

Article: 128. Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court Notwithstanding anything in this chapter, the Chief Justice of India may at any time, with the previous consent of the president, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court or of the Federal Court or who has held the office of a Judge of a High Court and is duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court to sit and act as a Judge of the Supreme Court, and every such person so requested shall, while so sitting and acting, be entitled to such allowances as the President may by order determine and have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of, but shall not otherwise be deemed to be, a Judge of that Court: Provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to require any such person as aforesaid to sit and act as a Judge of that Court unless he consents so to do
Title: Article 128 - Attendance of Retired Judges at Sittings of the Supreme Court
Description:
This article allows retired judges to come back and help the Supreme Court if needed.

The Chief Justice can ask a retired judge to sit in the Supreme Court, with the President’s approval.
The retired judge will have the same powers as a regular judge but will not be considered a permanent judge unless they agree to help.

Article: 129. Supreme Court to be a court of record The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself
Title: Article 129 - Supreme Court to be a Court of Record
Description:
The Supreme Court is an important court, and it keeps a record of all its decisions and actions.

This means it has the power to store records, and it can punish anyone who disrespects or doesn't follow its orders (contempt of court).

Article: 130. Seat of Supreme Court The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places, as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint
Title: Article 130 - Seat of Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court usually sits in Delhi, but the Chief Justice can decide to hold court in another place if needed, with the President’s approval.

Article:
131. Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Supreme Court shall, to the exclusion of any other court, have original jurisdiction in any dispute
 (a) between the Government of India and one or more States; or
 (b) between the Government of India and any State or States on one side and one or more other States on the other; or
 (c) between two or more States, if and in so far as the dispute involves any question (whether of law or fact) on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends: Provided that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to a dispute arising out of any treaty, agreement, covenant, engagements, and or other similar instrument which, having been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution, continues in operation after such commencement, or which provides that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to such a dispute
Title: Article 131 - Original Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Description:
The Supreme Court has the power to hear certain types of cases first (before any other court). These cases can be:

Disagreements between the Government of India and one or more states.
Disagreements between different states.
The Supreme Court decides such cases if they are about legal rights.
But, if the case is related to old agreements or treaties made before the Constitution started, the Supreme Court won’t handle it.

Article:
132. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in certain cases ( 1 ) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order of a High Court in the territory of India, whether in a civil, criminal or other proceeding, if the High Court certifies under Article 134A that the case involves a substantial question of law as t the interpretation of this Constitution
 (2) Omitted
 (3) Where such a certificate is given, any party in the case may appeal to the Supreme Court on the ground that any such question as aforesaid has been wrongly decided Explanation For the purposes of this article, the expression final order includes an order declaring an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case
Title: Article 132 - Appellate Jurisdiction of Supreme Court in Appeals from High Courts in Certain Cases
Description:
This article allows people to appeal to the Supreme Court if they think the High Court made a mistake in a big legal question about the Constitution.

If the High Court says the case involves a big legal question, anyone involved in the case can appeal to the Supreme Court.

Article:
133. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in regard to civil matters
 (1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court certifies under Article 134A
 (a) that the case involves a substantial question of law of general importance; and
 (b) that in the opinion of the High Court the said question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court
 (2) Notwithstanding anything in Article 132, any party appealing to the Supreme Court under clause ( 1 ) may urge as one of the grounds in such appeal that a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution has been wrongly decided
 (3) Notwithstanding anything in this article, no appeal shall, unless Parliament by law otherwise provides, lie to the Supreme Court from the judgment, decree or final order of one Judge of a High Court
Title: Article 133: Appellate Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in Civil Matters from High Courts
Description:
This article defines the procedure and conditions under which an appeal can be made to the Supreme Court of India from the High Courts in civil matters.

Clause 1: Appeal to the Supreme Court
An appeal can be made to the Supreme Court from a High Court's judgment, decree, or final order in a civil case, but only under the following conditions:

The High Court certifies the case under Article 134A:
Substantial Question of Law: The case must involve a substantial question of law of general importance. This means the legal issue is significant enough that it should be settled at the national level.
Need for Supreme Court Decision: The High Court must be of the opinion that this question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court. It indicates that the issue is important enough to require a final decision from the highest court.
Clause 2: Grounds for Appeal
Even if an appeal is made under Clause 1, the appellant (the person appealing) may also argue that:

A substantial question of law concerning the interpretation of the Constitution has been wrongly decided by the High Court. This provides the appellant the opportunity to challenge the High Court’s interpretation of constitutional matters.
Clause 3: Restrictions on Appeals from Single Judge of a High Court
No Appeal from a Single Judge: Generally, no appeal shall be made to the Supreme Court from the judgment, decree, or final order of a single judge of a High Court, unless Parliament makes a law allowing it.
This ensures that appeals from a single judge's decision of a High Court are limited, and the appeal process is typically reserved for decisions made by a larger bench of the High Court (a bench with more than one judge).

Article:
134. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in regard to criminal matters
 (1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court has on appeal reversed an order of acquittal of an accused person and sentenced him to death; or has withdrawn for trial before itself any case from any court subordinate to its authority and has in such trial convicted the accused person and sentenced him to death; or
 (c) certifies under Article 134A that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court: Provided that an appeal under sub clause (c) shall lie subject to such provisions as may be made in that behalf under clause ( 1 ) of Article 145 and to such conditions as the High Court may establish or require
 (2) Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court any further powers to entertain and hear appeals from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India subject to such conditions and limitations as may be specified in such law
134A. Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court Every High Court, passing or making a judgment, decree, final order, or sentence, referred to in clause ( 1 ) of Article 132 or clause ( 1 ) of Article 133, or clause ( 1 ) of Article 134
 (a) may, if it deems fit so to do, on its own motion; and
 (b) shall, if an oral application is made, by or on behalf of the party aggrieved, immediately after the passing or making of such judgment, decree, final order or sentence, determine, as soon as may be after such passing or making, the question whether a certificate of the nature referred to in clause ( 1 ) of Article 132, or clause ( 1 ) of Article 133 or, as the case may be, sub clause (c) of clause ( 1 ) of Article 134, may be given in respect of that case
Title: Article 134 - Appellate Jurisdiction of Supreme Court in Criminal Matters and Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court
Description:
This article talks about criminal cases (cases where someone is accused of breaking the law).

People can appeal to the Supreme Court if the High Court:
Changes a judgment and sentences someone to death.
Takes a case from a lower court and sentences someone to death.
The Supreme Court will also hear appeals if the High Court says the case is important and needs the Supreme Court’s attention.
Parliament can also make laws to give the Supreme Court more power in hearing criminal appeals.

When a High Court makes an important decision, it can give a ""certificate"" saying that the case is important enough to be appealed in the Supreme Court.
If a person wants to appeal, they can ask the High Court for this certificate right after the decision is made, and the High Court will decide whether to give it.

Article: 135. Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of Article 133 or Article 134 do not apply if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court immediately before the commencement of this Constitution under any existing law
Title: Article 135 - Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court
Description: Before India’s Constitution, there was a Federal Court. If a case wasn't covered by the Articles about High Courts, the Federal Court could handle it. After the Constitution, the Supreme Court can take on those responsibilities.

Article:
136. Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
 (1) Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any court or tribunal in the territory of India
 (2) Nothing in clause ( 1 ) shall apply to any judgment, determination, sentence or order passed or made by any court or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces
Title: Article 136 - Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
Description:
The Supreme Court has the power to allow someone to appeal to it from any court in India, even if the law doesn’t automatically allow it. This is called "special leave" and is given at the Supreme Court's discretion.
However, this does not apply to cases involving the Armed Forces.

Article: 137. Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under Article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it
Title: Article 137 - Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court can review its own decisions. If it made a mistake, it can correct it. The Parliament might also make rules about how the Court can do this.

Article:
138. Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
 (1) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law confer
 (2) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction, and powers with respect to any matter as the Government of India and the Government of any State may by special agreement confer, if Parliament by law provides for the exercise of such jurisdiction and powers by the Supreme Court
Title: Article 138 - Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court’s powers can be expanded by Parliament. If Parliament decides that the Supreme Court should handle more types of cases, it can give the Court extra authority.

Article:
139. Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court power to issue directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for any purposes other than those mentioned in clause ( 2 ) of Article 32
139A. Transfer of certain cases
 (1) Where cases involving the same or substantially the same questions of law are pending before the Supreme Court and one or more High Courts or before two or more High Courts and the Supreme Court is satisfied on its own motion or an application made by the Attorney General of India or by a party to any such case that such questions are substantial questions of general importance, the Supreme Court may withdraw the case or cases pending before the High Court or the High Courts and dispose of all the cases itself: Provided that the Supreme Court may after determining the said questions of law return any case so withdrawn together with a copy of its judgment on such questions to the High Court from which the case has been withdrawn, and the High Court shall on receipt thereof, proceed to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment
 (2) The Supreme Court may, if it deems it expedient so to do for the ends of justice, transfer any case, appeal or other proceedings pending before any High Court to any other High Court
Title: Article 139 - Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs and Transfer of certain cases
Description:
Parliament can give the Supreme Court the power to issue orders or ""writs"" like habeas corpus, mandamus, and others. These orders are used to protect people’s rights and ensure justice."
If there are multiple cases about the same legal question, the Supreme Court can take them all and decide the issue. If needed, the Supreme Court can also move cases from one High Court to another for easier justice.
Parliament can give the Supreme Court the power to issue orders or "writs" like habeas corpus, mandamus, and others. These orders are used to protect people’s rights and ensure justice.

Article: 140. Ancillary powers of Supreme Court Parliament may by law make provision for conferring upon the Supreme Court such supplemental powers not inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Constitution as may appear to be necessary or desirable for the purpose of enabling the Court more effectively to exercise the jurisdiction conferred upon it by or under this Constitution
Title: Article 140 - Ancillary powers of Supreme Court
Description: Parliament can give the Supreme Court additional powers if needed to help it do its job better, as long as those powers don't conflict with the Constitution.

Article: 141. Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India
Title: Article 141 - Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts
Description: Any decision made by the Supreme Court on a law must be followed by all other courts in India. This ensures that the law is applied the same way everywhere.

Article:
142. Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court and unless as to discovery, etc ( 1 ) The Supreme Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction may pass such decree or make such order as is necessary for doing complete justice in any cause or matter pending before it, and any decree so passed or orders so made shall be enforceable throughout the territory of India in such manner as may be prescribed by or under any law made by Parliament and, until provision in that behalf is so made, in such manner as the President may by order prescribe
 (2) Subject to the provisions of any law made in this behalf by Parliament, the Supreme Court shall, as respects the whole of the territory of India, have all and every power to make any order for the purpose of securing the attendance of any person, the discovery or production of any documents, or the investigation or punishment of any contempt of itself
Title: Article 142 - Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court
Description: If the Supreme Court makes a decision, it can issue orders that must be followed across India. The President can also make sure the orders are followed. The Supreme Court can even make orders to force people to attend court, produce documents, or punish those who disrespect the Court.

Article:
143. Power of President to consult Supreme Court ( 1 ) If at any time it appears to the President that a question of law or fact has arisen, or is likely to arise, which is of such a nature and of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the opinion of the Supreme Court upon it, he may refer the question to that Court for consideration and the Court may, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon
 (2) The President may, notwithstanding anything in the proviso to Article 131, refer a dispute of the kind mentioned in the said proviso to the Supreme Court for opinion and the Supreme Court shall, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon
Title: Article 143 - Power of President to consult Supreme Court
Description:
If the President thinks a question of law is very important and needs clarity, they can ask the Supreme Court for its opinion. The Supreme Court will consider the issue and give its opinion.
The President can also ask the Supreme Court about disputes between states and the central government.

Article: 144. Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court All authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court
Title: Article 144 - Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court
Description: All government authorities and courts in India must help the Supreme Court in its work. This ensures that the Supreme Court’s orders are carried out.

Title: Article 145: Rules of Court, etc.
Description:
This article grants the Supreme Court the authority to establish its own rules of practice and procedure, subject to the laws made by Parliament and with the approval of the President.

Key Provisions of Article 145:
Supreme Court's Power to Make Rules (Clause 1):

The Supreme Court can create rules to regulate the practice and procedure of the Court. This includes a wide range of matters, such as:
Rules for practitioners: The Court can set rules for the individuals or entities who may practice before it.
Appeals procedure: It can create rules for hearing appeals, including the time limits within which appeals must be filed.
Enforcement of rights: The Court can establish rules regarding proceedings to enforce rights granted by Part III of the Constitution (Fundamental Rights).
Article 139A procedures: Rules can be made for proceedings under Article 139A (transfer of cases to the Supreme Court).
Appeals under Article 134: The Court can create rules for entertaining appeals under specific provisions of Article 134 (regarding appeals in criminal matters).
Review of judgments: The Court can establish procedures for reviewing its own judgments or orders, including the time within which review applications must be filed.
Costs and fees: Rules regarding the costs involved in any proceedings and the fees that should be charged for those proceedings.
Bail: Rules for the granting of bail in cases heard by the Supreme Court.
Stay of proceedings: Rules concerning the stay of proceedings.
Frivolous appeals: Rules allowing the summary dismissal of frivolous or vexatious appeals.
Inquiries under Article 317: The Court can regulate the procedure for inquiries referred to in Article 317 (related to removal of certain public servants).
Minimum Number of Judges for Certain Cases (Clause 2 and 3):

Clause 2: The Supreme Court rules may fix the minimum number of judges required to hear a case or perform a function. It can also provide for the powers of single judges or division benches (a bench with more than one judge).
Clause 3: For cases involving substantial constitutional questions, a minimum of five judges must hear the case. This also applies to references made under Article 143.
However, if a smaller bench (less than five judges) hears a case and finds a substantial constitutional question that must be addressed, the bench must refer the issue to a larger bench (five judges or more). Once the larger bench delivers its opinion, the smaller bench will dispose of the case based on that opinion.
Judgment Delivery (Clause 4):

Open Court Delivery: The Supreme Court must deliver its judgments in open court. This ensures transparency and accountability in the judicial process.
Article 143 Opinion: Similarly, any report or opinion under Article 143 (which involves the President seeking advice from the Supreme Court on legal matters) must also be delivered in open court.
Majority for Judgment (Clause 5):

For any judgment or opinion to be delivered, it must have the concurrence of the majority of the judges present in the hearing.
However, a judge who does not agree with the majority can still deliver a dissenting judgment or opinion.

Article:
146. Officers and servants and the expenses of the Supreme Court
 (1) Appointments of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be made by the Chief Justice of India or such other Judge or officer of the Court as he may direct: Provided that the President may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule, no person not already attached to the Court shall be appointed to any office connected with the Court, save after consultation with the Union Public Service Commission
 (2) Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of India or by some other Judge or officer of the Court authorised by the Chief Justice of India to make rules for the purpose: Provided that the rules made under this clause shall, so far as they relate to salaries, allowances, leave or pensions, require the approval of the President
 (3) The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the offices and servants of the Court, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India, and any fees or other moneys taken by the court shall form part of that Fund
Title: Article 146: Officers and Servants and the Expenses of the Supreme Court
Description:
This article outlines the provisions related to the appointments, conditions of service, and expenses of the officers and servants working in the Supreme Court of India.

Key Provisions of Article 146:
Appointments of Officers and Servants (Clause 1):

Appointments for officers and servants of the Supreme Court will be made by the Chief Justice of India (CJI) or by another judge or officer as directed by the CJI.
Consultation with the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC):
The President of India can issue rules requiring that in certain cases, no person who is not already attached to the Supreme Court should be appointed to any office connected with the Court, unless consulted with the UPSC.
Conditions of Service (Clause 2):

The conditions of service (such as work duties, roles, and responsibilities) for officers and servants will be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of India or a designated officer/judge authorized by the CJI.
However, if these rules relate to salaries, allowances, leave, or pensions, they require the approval of the President of India.
Administrative Expenses (Clause 3):

The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court (including salaries, allowances, and pensions for officers and servants) are to be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India.
Any fees or other money collected by the Court will also become part of the Consolidated Fund of India

Article: 147. Interpretation In this Chapter and in Chapter V of Part VI references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution shall be construed as including references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Government of India Act, 1935 (including any enactment amending or supplementing that Act), or of any Order in Council or order made thereunder, or of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 , or of any order made thereunder CHAPTER V COMPTROLLER AND AUDITOR GENERAL OF INDIA
Title: Article 147: Interpretation
Description: This article is about how to interpret certain laws or constitutional questions. If there’s any doubt about how to understand the Constitution or older laws like the Government of India Act of 1935, it should be treated as a big question about the Constitution.

Article:
148. Comptroller and Auditor General of India
 (1) There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor General of India who shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal and shall only be removed from office in like manner and on the like grounds as a Judge of the Supreme Court
 (2) Every person appointed to be the Comptroller and Auditor General of India shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
 (3) The salary and other conditions of service of the Comptroller and Auditor General shall be such as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until they are so determined, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule: Provided that neither the salary of a Comptroller and Auditor General nor his rights in respect of leave of absence, pension or age of retirement shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment
 (4) The Comptroller and Auditor General shall not be eligible for further office either under the Government of India or under the Government of any State after he has ceased to hold his office
 (5) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service of persons serving in the Indian Audit and Accounts Department and the administrative powers of the Comptroller and Auditor General shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the President after consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor General
 (6) The Administrative expenses of the office of the Comptroller and Auditor General, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of pensions serving in that office, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India
Title: Article 148: Comptroller and Auditor General of India
Description:
This article establishes the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India, outlining the office's appointment, conditions of service, powers, and remuneration.

Key Provisions of Article 148:
Appointment and Removal (Clause 1):

The Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG) is appointed by the President of India by a warrant under his hand and seal.
The removal of the CAG can only occur in the same manner and on the same grounds as the removal of a Supreme Court judge (i.e., through an address by both Houses of Parliament supported by a majority).
Oath or Affirmation (Clause 2):

Before assuming office, the CAG must make and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before the President or a person designated by the President, according to the form in the Third Schedule of the Constitution.
Salary and Conditions of Service (Clause 3):

The salary and conditions of service of the CAG are determined by Parliament through law. Until Parliament makes this law, they are specified in the Second Schedule.
Salary Protection: The salary, leave, pension, and retirement age of the CAG cannot be reduced to their disadvantage after the appointment.
Eligibility for Further Office (Clause 4):

Once the CAG has ceased to hold office, he is not eligible for further office under the Government of India or the State Governments.
Conditions of Service for Audit Department Personnel (Clause 5):

The conditions of service of the personnel in the Indian Audit and Accounts Department and the administrative powers of the CAG are prescribed by rules made by the President, in consultation with the CAG.
Administrative Expenses (Clause 6):

The administrative expenses of the CAG's office, including salaries, allowances, and pensions of the personnel, are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.

Article: 149. Duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor General The Comptroller and Auditor General shall perform such duties and exercise such powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States and of any other authority or body as may be prescribed by or under any law made by Parliament and, until provision in that behalf is so made, shall perform such duties and exercise such powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States as were conferred on or exercisable by the Auditor General of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution in relation to the accounts of the Dominion of India and of the Provinces respectively
Title: Article 149: Duties and Powers of the Comptroller and Auditor General
Description: The CAG has to check the accounts of the Union (central government), states, and any other organization the Parliament chooses. They do this based on the rules set by the Parliament, or if the Parliament hasn’t made any rules, the CAG will follow the rules that were in place before the Constitution.

Article: 150. Form of accounts of the Union and of the States The accounts of the Union and of the States shall be kept in such form as the President may, on the advice of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India, prescribe
Title: Article 150: Form of Accounts of the Union and States
Description: The CAG helps decide the way the Union and state accounts should be kept. The President listens to the CAG’s advice to make these rules.

Article:
151. Audit reports
 (1) The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India relating to the accounts of the Union shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid before each House of Parliament
 (2) The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India relating to the accounts of a State shall be submitted to the Governor of the State, who shall cause them to be laid before the Legislature of the State PART VI THE STATES CHAPTER I GENERAL
Title: Article 151: Audit Reports
Description:
Union Reports: The CAG’s reports about the Union’s accounts go to the President, who then sends them to Parliament.
State Reports: The CAG’s reports about a state’s accounts go to the state’s Governor, who sends them to the state legislature.

Article: 152. Definition In this Part, unless the context otherwise, requires, the expression State does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir CHAPTER II THE EXECUTIVE The Governor
Title: Article 152: Definition
Description: In this article, the word "State" does not include Jammu and Kashmir. This was true before the special status of Jammu and Kashmir was removed (which happened after Article 370 was modified).

Article: 153. Governors of States There shall be Governor for each State: Provided that nothing in this article shall prevent the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more States
Title: Article 153: Governors of States
Description: Every state in India has a Governor, and in some cases, the same person can be the Governor of more than one state.

Article:
154. Executive power of State
 (1) The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution
 (2) Nothing in this article shall
 (a) be deemed to transfer to the Governor any functions conferred by any existing law on any other authority; or
 (b) prevent Parliament or the Legislature of the State from conferring by law functions on any authority subordinate to the Governor
Title: Article 154: Executive Power of State
Description:
This article outlines the distribution of executive power at the State level in India, specifying the role of the Governor and the delegation of executive functions.

Key Provisions of Article 154:
Vesting of Executive Power (Clause 1):

The executive power of the State is vested in the Governor.
The Governor exercises this power either directly or through officers subordinate to him, as per the provisions of the Constitution.
Exceptions to the Executive Power (Clause 2):

Clause 2 ensures certain exceptions to the Governor's executive powers:
(a) It does not transfer to the Governor any functions that existing laws have already conferred on any other authority.
(b) It does not prevent Parliament or the State Legislature from delegating functions to authorities that are subordinate to the Governor.

Article: 155. Appointment of Governor The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal
Title: Article 155: Appointment of Governor
Description: The President appoints the Governor of each state. The Governor’s appointment is formalized with a document signed by the President.

Article:
156. Term of office of Governor
 (1) The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President
 (2) The Governor may, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign his office
 (3) Subject to the foregoing provisions of this article, a Governor shall hold for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office
 (4) Provided that a Governor shall, notwithstanding the expiration of his term, continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office
Title: Article 156: Term of Office of Governor
Description:
This article details the term of office and conditions under which a Governor holds office in a state in India.

Key Provisions of Article 156:
Term of Office (Clause 1):

A Governor holds office during the pleasure of the President. This means the President can remove the Governor at any time without assigning any reason, although in practice, Governors generally serve a fixed term unless dismissed earlier.
Resignation (Clause 2):

A Governor can resign from office by submitting a written resignation addressed to the President.
Fixed Term (Clause 3):

A Governor holds office for a term of five years starting from the day they assume office, subject to the President's pleasure.
Continuation after Term (Clause 4):

Even after the expiration of the five-year term, a Governor continues to hold office until their successor assumes office.

Article: 157. Qualifications for appointment as Governor No person shall be eligible for appointment as Governor unless he is a citizen of India and has completed the age of thirty five years
Title: Article 157: Qualifications for Appointment as Governor
Description:
To become a Governor, a person must:

Be an Indian citizen.
Be at least 35 years old.

Article:
158. Conditions of Governor office
 (1) The Governor shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State specified in the First Schedule, and if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any such State be appointed Governor, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as Governor
 (2) The Governor shall not hold any other office of profit
 (3) The Governor shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences and shall be also entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such emoluments, allowances and privileges as are specified in Second Schedule
 (3A) Where the same person is appointed as Governor of two or more States, the emoluments and allowances payable to the Governor shall be allocated among the States in such proportion as the President may by order determine
 (4) The emoluments and allowances of the Governor shall not be diminished during his term of office
Title: Article 158: Conditions of Governor's Office
Description:
This article outlines the conditions related to the office of the Governor in an Indian state.

Key Provisions of Article 158:
Disqualification from Legislative Membership (Clause 1):

A Governor cannot be a member of Parliament or any State Legislature.
If a Member of Parliament or a State Legislature is appointed as a Governor, they are considered to have vacated their seat in the legislature the moment they assume office as Governor.
Prohibition on Holding Another Office of Profit (Clause 2):

A Governor cannot hold any other office of profit. This ensures that the Governor’s position remains independent and free from any other financial or professional commitments.
Entitlement to Residence, Emoluments, and Privileges (Clause 3):

The Governor is entitled to use the official residence without paying rent.
The Governor is also entitled to emoluments, allowances, and privileges as determined by Parliament through law.
Until Parliament makes such provisions, the Governor is entitled to the emoluments, allowances, and privileges as specified in the Second Schedule.
Governors of Multiple States (Clause 3A):

If the same person is appointed as Governor of two or more states, the emoluments and allowances for the Governor are to be allocated among the states. The President will determine the allocation by order.
Protection from Salary Reduction (Clause 4):

The emoluments and allowances of the Governor cannot be diminished during their term of office. This ensures that the Governor's compensation remains stable throughout their tenure.

Article: 159.
