Oath or affirmation by Governor Every Governor and every person discharging the functions of the Governor shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe in the presence of the chief Justice of the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to the State, or, in his absence, the senior most Judge of that court available, an oath or affirmation in the following form, that is to say swear in the name of God I, A B, do that I solemnly affirm will faithfully execute the office of Governor (or discharge the functions of the Governor) of (name of the State) and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law and that I will devote myself to the service and well being of the people of (name of the State)
Title: Article 159: Oath or Affirmation by Governor
Description: Before taking office, the Governor must swear an oath to protect the Constitution and serve the people of the state to the best of their ability.

Article: 160. Discharge of the functions of the Governor in certain contingencies The President may make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of a State in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter
Title: Article 160: Discharge of the Functions of the Governor in Certain Contingencies
Description: If something unexpected happens and the Governor cannot perform their duties, the President can make arrangements for someone else to perform those functions.

Article: 161. Power of Governor to grant pardons, etc, and to suspend, remit or commute sentences in certain cases The Governor of a State shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends
Title: Article 161: Power of Governor to Grant Pardons, Etc.
Description: The Governor can forgive crimes (grant pardons) or change punishments in cases related to state laws. This is like a special power to show mercy.

Article: 162. Extent of executive power of State Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the executive power of a State shall extend to the matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has power to make laws Provided that in any matter with respect to which the Legislature of a State and Parliament have power to make laws, the executive power of the State shall be subject to, and limited by, the executive power expressly conferred by the Constitution or by any law made by Parliament upon the Union or authorities thereof Council of Ministers
Title: Article 162: Extent of Executive Power of State
Description: The executive powers of a state are limited to the matters where the state legislature can make laws. However, if both the state and central government can make laws on a subject, the state’s executive power is limited by the central government’s laws.

Article:
163. Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor
 (1) There shall be a council of Ministers with the chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor in the exercise of his functions, except in so far as he is by or under this constitution required to exercise his functions or any of them in his discretion
 (2) If any question arises whether any matter is or is not a matter as respects which the Governor is by or under this Constitution required to act in his discretion, the decision of the Governor in his discretion shall be final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor shall not be called in question on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in his discretion
 (3) The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the Governor shall not be inquired into in any court
Title: Article 163: Council of Ministers to Aid and Advise Governor
Description:
This article describes the role of the Council of Ministers in assisting the Governor in the exercise of his functions, as well as the scope of the Governor's discretion.

Key Provisions of Article 163:
Council of Ministers to Aid and Advise the Governor (Clause 1):

Every Governor is aided and advised by a Council of Ministers, headed by the Chief Minister.
This council helps the Governor in performing most of his functions.
However, there are instances where the Governor may be required to act in his discretion, in which case the advice of the Council of Ministers may not be binding on him.
Governor’s Discretion (Clause 2):

If there is a dispute about whether a particular matter requires the Governor to act in his discretion, the Governor's decision on whether or not he is exercising discretion is final.
This means that the validity of the Governor's actions cannot be challenged in court on the grounds that the Governor should have acted with or without the advice of the Council of Ministers.
Inquiries into Ministerial Advice (Clause 3):

Courts cannot inquire into what advice was given by the Council of Ministers to the Governor.
The Governor's decision, based on the advice received, is not subject to judicial review.

Article:
164. Other provisions as to Ministers
 (1) The chief Minister shall be appointed by the Governor and the other Ministers shall be appointed by the Governor on the advice of the Chief Minister, and the Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor: Provided that in the State of Bihar, Madhya Pradesh and Orissa, there shall be a Minister in charge of tribal welfare who may in addition be in charge of the welfare of the Scheduled Castes and backward classes or any other work
 (2) The Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly of the State
 (3) Before a Minister enters upon his office, the Governor shall administer so him the oaths of office and of secrecy according to the forms set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
 (4) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of the Legislature of the State shall at the expiration of that period cease to be a Minister
 (5) The salaries and allowances of Ministers shall be such as the Legislature of the State may from time to time by law determine and, until the Legislature of the State so determines, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule The Advocate General for the State
Title: Article 164: Other Provisions as to Ministers
Description:
This article outlines the appointment, responsibilities, and qualifications for Ministers in the States of India.

Key Provisions of Article 164:
Appointment of Chief Minister and Other Ministers (Clause 1):

The Governor appoints the Chief Minister.
The other Ministers are appointed by the Governor on the advice of the Chief Minister.
The Ministers hold office at the pleasure of the Governor.
A special provision applies to the States of Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, and Orissa, where there must be a Minister in charge of tribal welfare, who may also handle the welfare of Scheduled Castes, backward classes, or other duties.
Collective Responsibility of the Council of Ministers (Clause 2):

The Council of Ministers, headed by the Chief Minister, is collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly of the State.
This means that if the Legislative Assembly passes a vote of no confidence, all the Ministers in the state must resign collectively.
Oaths of Office and Secrecy (Clause 3):

Before a Minister takes office, the Governor administers an oath of office and an oath of secrecy, according to the forms specified in the Third Schedule.
Term of Office for Ministers (Clause 4):

A Minister who is not a member of the State Legislature for six consecutive months will automatically cease to be a Minister at the end of that period.
This ensures that all Ministers remain accountable to the legislature.
Salaries and Allowances of Ministers (Clause 5):

The salaries and allowances of Ministers are determined by the State Legislature.
If the Legislature has not set the salaries, they will be as specified in the Second Schedule.

Article:
165. Advocate General for the State
 (1) The Governor of each State shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of a High Court to be Advocate General for the State
 (2) It shall be the duty of the Advocate General to give advice to the Government of the State upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may from time to time be referred or assigned to him by the Governor, and to discharge the functions conferred on him by or under this Constitution or any other law for the time being in force
 (3) The Advocate General shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor, and shall receive such remuneration as the Governor may determine Conduct of Government Business
Title: Article 165: Advocate General for the State
Description:
1. Appointment of Advocate General:
The Governor of each State shall appoint a person as the Advocate General for the State.
The person appointed must be qualified to be appointed a Judge of a High Court.
2. Duties of the Advocate General:
The Advocate General shall:
Give legal advice to the Government of the State on legal matters.
Perform other legal duties assigned by the Governor.
Discharge functions given to him by the Constitution or any other law in force.
3. Tenure and Remuneration:
The Advocate General holds office during the pleasure of the Governor, meaning the Governor can remove the Advocate General at any time.
The Advocate General shall receive such remuneration (salary or payment) as the Governor may determine.

Article:
166. Conduct of business of the Government of a State
 (1) All executive action of the Government of a State shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor
 (2) Orders and other instruments made and executed in the name of the Governor shall be authenticated in such manner as may be specified in rules to be made by the Governor, and the validity of an order on instruction which is so authenticated shall not be called in question on the ground that it is not an order or instrument made or executed by the Governor
 (3) The Governor shall make rules for the more convenient transaction of the business of the Government of the State, and for the allocation among Ministers of the said business in so far as it is not business with respect to which the Governor is by or under this Constitution required to act in his discretion
Title: Article 166: Conduct of business of the Government of a State
Description:
1. Executive Action in the Name of the Governor:
All executive actions taken by the Government of a State must be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor.
This means that any action or decision made by the State government is officially carried out under the name of the Governor, even if it is executed by someone else, like a Minister or official.
2. Authentication of Orders:
Orders and instruments made or executed in the name of the Governor must be authenticated according to the rules specified by the Governor.
The rules will determine how these orders are verified as valid.
The validity of an order or instrument that is authenticated in this manner cannot be challenged on the grounds that it was not made or executed by the Governor personally.
3. Rules for the Conduct of Government Business:
The Governor is responsible for making rules that ensure the smooth transaction of business within the Government of the State.
These rules also cover how the business is allocated among Ministers.
However, the Governor's discretion applies to matters where the Constitution requires him to act personally or without Ministerial advice.

Article:
167. Duties of Chief Minister as respects the furnishing of information to Governor, etc It shall be the duty of the Chief Minister of each State
 (a) to communicate to the Governor of the State all decisions of the council of Ministers relating to the administration of the affairs of the State and proposals for legislation;
 (b) to furnish such information relating to the administration of the affairs of the State and proposals for legislation as the Governor may call for; and
 (c) if the Governor so requires, to submit for the consideration of the Council of Ministers any matter on which a decision has been taken by a Minister but which has not been considered by the Council CHAPTER III THE STATE LEGISLATURE General
Title: Article 167: Duties of Chief Minister as Respects the Furnishing of Information to Governor, etc.
Description:
(a) Communication of Decisions to the Governor:
The Chief Minister must communicate to the Governor of the State all decisions made by the Council of Ministers. This includes:
Decisions related to the administration of the State's affairs.
Proposals for legislation (laws to be made).
(b) Furnishing Information on Request:
The Chief Minister must provide any information related to the administration of the State or proposals for legislation that the Governor may ask for.
This ensures the Governor is kept informed about the State's administration and plans.
(c) Submission of Matters for Consideration:
If the Governor asks, the Chief Minister must submit any matter to the Council of Ministers for discussion, if:
A Minister has already made a decision on it but it has not yet been considered by the Council of Ministers.
This allows the Governor to ensure that important matters are properly discussed at the highest level of the State government.

Article:
168. Constitution of Legislatures in States
 (1) For every State there shall be a Legislature which shall consist of the Governor, and
 (a) in the States of Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka and Uttar Pradesh, two houses:
 (b) in other States, one House
 (2) Where there are two Houses of the Legislature of a State, one shall be known as the Legislative Council and the other as the Legislative Assembly, and where there is only one House, it shall be known as the Legislative Assembly
Title: Article 168: Constitution of Legislatures in States
Description:
(1) Legislature in Every State:
Every State in India must have a Legislature. This Legislature consists of:

The Governor (who represents the executive power in the state).
Two houses of the Legislature in some States, and one house in others.
Details:

In the following States, there are two houses in the Legislature:
Bihar
Madhya Pradesh
Maharashtra
Karnataka
Uttar Pradesh
In all other States, the Legislature has one house.
(2) Names of the Houses:
Where there are two houses in a State’s Legislature:
One house is called the Legislary Council.
The other house is called the Legislary Assembly.
Where there is only one house, it is known as the Legislary Assembly.

Article:
169. Abolition or creation of Legislative Councils in States
 (1) Notwithstanding anything in Article 168, Parliament may by law provide for the abolition of the Legislative Council of a State having such a Council or for the creation of such a Council in a State having no such Council, if the Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to that effect by a majority of the total membership of the Assembly and by a majority of not less than two thirds of the members of the Assembly present and voting
 (2) Any law referred to in clause ( 1 ) shall contain such provisions for the amendment of this Constitution as may be necessary to give effect to the provisions of the law and may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions as Parliament may deem necessary
 (3) No such law as aforesaid shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of Article 368
Title: Article 169: Abolition or Creation of Legislative Councils in States
Description:
(1) Abolition or Creation of Legislative Council:
Despite what is mentioned in Article 168, Parliament can pass a law to either:

Abolish the Legislative Council in a State that currently has one, or
Create a Legislative Council in a State that does not have one.
However, this can only happen if:

The Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to this effect.
The resolution must be passed by:
A majority of the total membership of the Assembly, and
A majority of at least two-thirds of the members present and voting.
(2) Provisions of the Law:
The law passed by Parliament for creating or abolishing a Legislative Council will:
Include any necessary changes to the Constitution to implement the law.
May also contain any supplementary or incidental provisions Parliament deems necessary.
(3) Not an Amendment of the Constitution:
Any law made under this article will not be treated as an amendment of the Constitution for the purposes of Article 368 (which deals with the procedure for amending the Constitution).

Article:
170. Composition of the Legislative Assemblies
 (1) Subject to the provisions of Article 333, the Legislative Assembly of each State shall consist of not more than five hundred, and not less than sixty, members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State
 (2) For the purposes of clause ( 1 ), each State shall be divided into territorial constituencies in such manner that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the State Explanation In this clause, the expression population means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published: Provided that the reference in this Explanation to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2000 have been published, be construed as a reference to the 1971 census
 (3) Upon the completion of each census, the total number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of each State and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine: Provided that such readjustment shall not affect representation in the Legislative Assembly until the dissolution of the then existing Assembly: Provided further that such readjustment shall take effect from such date as the President may, by order, specify and until such readjustment takes effect, any election to the Legislative Assembly may be held on the basis of the territorial constituencies existing before such readjustment: Provided also that until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2000 have been published, it shall not be necessary to readjust the total number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of each State and the division of such State into territorial constituencies under this clause
Title: Article 170: Composition of the Legislative Assemblies
Description:
(1) Number of Members:
Each State’s Legislative Assembly will have:
Not more than 500 members, and
Not fewer than 60 members.
These members are directly elected from territorial constituencies within the State.
(2) Division into Constituencies:
Each State will be divided into territorial constituencies for elections.
The division should ensure that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allocated to it is as equal as possible throughout the State.
Explanation:
The population refers to the population as determined by the most recent census whose figures have been published.
Until the first census after the year 2000 is published, the population will be based on the 1971 census.
(3) Readjustment of Seats and Constituencies:
After every census, the total number of seats and the division of constituencies in the Legislative Assembly must be readjusted.
The readjustment will be done by an authority determined by Parliament, as specified by law.
Key Provisions:
The readjustment will not affect the current Assembly until it is dissolved.
The readjustment will take effect from a date specified by the President.
Until the new readjustment takes effect, elections can still be held based on the old constituencies.
Until the first census after 2000 is available, no readjustment of seats or constituencies is necessary.

Title: Article 171: Composition of the Legislative Councils
Description:
(1) Number of Members in the Legislative Council:
The total number of members in a State’s Legislative Council (if the State has one) cannot exceed one-third of the total members in that State’s Legislative Assembly.
However, the Legislative Council must have at least 40 members, no matter the size of the Assembly.
(2) Composition as per Law:
Until Parliament makes a law to change it, the composition of the Legislative Council will be as provided in clause (3).
(3) Breakdown of the Legislative Council Members:
The members of the Legislative Council will be elected or nominated in the following way:

One-third of the members will be elected by electorates consisting of members from:

Municipalities,
District boards, and
Other local authorities specified by Parliament.
One-twelfth of the members will be elected by electorates consisting of:

Graduates who have been living in the State for at least three years and are graduates from any Indian university or hold qualifications equivalent to a graduate degree under laws made by Parliament.
One-twelfth of the members will be elected by electorates consisting of:

Teachers who have been engaged in teaching in institutions that are not lower than a secondary school, and who have been doing so for three years.
One-third of the members will be elected by the members of the Legislative Assembly of the State. These elected members cannot already be part of the Assembly.

The remaining members will be nominated by the Governor. The Governor nominates people with special knowledge or practical experience in areas such as:

Literature,
Science,
Art,
Cooperative movement, and
Social service.
(4) Method of Election:
The members elected under clauses (a), (b), and (c) will be chosen in territorial constituencies as prescribed by Parliament.
Elections will be held using the proportional representation system through the single transferable vote (STV) system, which ensures that the votes are distributed proportionally.
(5) Nominated Members:
The members nominated by the Governor will be people with special expertise or practical experience in areas like:
Literature,
Science,
Art,
Cooperative movements, and
Social services.

Article:
172. Duration of State Legislatures
 (1) Every Legislative Assembly of every State, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer and the expiration of the said period of five years shall operate as a dissolution of the Assembly: Provided that the said period may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, be extended by Parliament by law for a period not exceeding one year at a time and not extending in any case beyond a period of six months after the Proclamation has ceased to operate
Title: Article 172: Duration of State Legislatures
Description:
A Legislative Assembly in a state lasts for five years from its first meeting unless it is dissolved sooner.
If a state emergency is in place, Parliament can extend this period by one year at a time but not beyond six months after the emergency ends.

Article:
173. Qualification for membership of the State Legislature A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in the Legislature of a State unless he
 (a) is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf by the Election Commission an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule;
 (b) is, in the case of a seat in the Legislative Assembly, not less than twenty five years of age and in the case of a seat in the Legislative Council, not less than thirty years of age; and
 (c) possesses such other qualifications as may be prescribed in that behalf by or under any law made by Parliament
Title: Article 173: Qualification for Membership of the State Legislature
Description:
To become a member of a State Legislature, a person must:
Be a citizen of India.
Be 25 years old for a Legislative Assembly seat and 30 years old for a Legislative Council seat.
Meet any additional qualifications set by law.

Article:
174. Sessions of the State Legislature, prorogation and dissolution
 (1) The Governor shall from time to time summon the House or each House of the Legislature of the State to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session
 (2) The Governor may from time to time
 (a) Prorogue the House or either House;
 (b) dissolve the Legislative Assembly
Title: Article 174: Sessions of the State Legislature, Prorogation and Dissolution
Description:
(1) Summoning the Legislature:
The Governor is responsible for summoning the House or both Houses of the State Legislature to meet at times and places of his choosing. However, there are time limits:
There must not be a gap of more than six months between the last sitting of the Legislature in one session and the first sitting of the next session.
(2) Prorogation and Dissolution:
The Governor has the authority to take the following actions:

Prorogue the House or either of the Houses. (Prorogation is the formal ending of a session of the Legislature without dissolving it.)
Dissolve the Legislative Assembly (Dissolution refers to the formal termination of the current Legislature, leading to new elections for members).

Article:
175. Right of Governor to address and send messages to the House or Houses
 (1) The Governor may address the Legislative Assembly or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, either House of the Legislature of the State, or both Houses assembled together, and may for that purpose require the attendance of members
 (2) The Governor may sent messages to the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in the Legislature or otherwise, and a House to which any message is so sent shall with all convenient dispatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration
Title: Article 175: Right of Governor to Address and Send Messages to the Legislature
Description:
The Governor can address the Legislative Assembly or both Houses of the Legislature.
The Governor can also send messages to the Legislature, and the members must consider the matters raised in the message.

Article:
176. Special address by the Governor
 (1) At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the Legislative Assembly and at the commencement of the first session of each year, the Governor shall address the Legislative Assembly or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, both House assembled together and inform the Legislature of the causes of its summons
 (2) Provision shall be made by the rules regulating the procedure of the House or either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to in such address
Title: Article 176: Special Address by the Governor
Description: After each general election and at the start of every year, the Governor addresses the State Legislature, informing it of the reasons for the session.

Article: 177. Rights of Ministers and Advocate General as respects the Houses Every Minister and the Advocate General for a State shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the legislative Assembly of the State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, both Houses, and to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, any committee of the Legislature of which he may be named a member, but shall not, by virtue of this article, be entitled to vote Officers of the State Legislature
Title: Article 177: Rights of Ministers and Advocate General
Description: Ministers and the Advocate General can speak in the State Legislature and participate in its proceedings but cannot vote unless they are also members of the Legislature.

Article: 178. The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly Every Legislative Assembly of a State shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Assembly to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speakers thereof and, so often as the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the Assembly shall choose another member to be Speaker or Deputy Speaker, as the case may be
Title: Article 178: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly
Description: Every Legislative Assembly must choose a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker. If the position becomes vacant, another member must be chosen.

Title: Article 179: Vacation and Resignation of the Offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Description:
A Speaker or Deputy Speaker must leave office if they stop being a member of the Assembly or if they resign in writing.
The Speaker can be removed by a resolution passed by the Assembly after giving 14 days' notice.

Article:
180. Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker
 (1) While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or, if the office of Deputy Speaker is also vacant, by such member of the Assembly as the Governor may appoint for the purpose
 (2) During the absence of the Speaker from any sitting of the Assembly the Deputy Speaker or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the assembly, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the Assembly, shall act as Speaker
Title: Article 180: Power of the Deputy Speaker or Other Person to Perform the Duties of the Office of, or to Act as, Speaker
Description:
(1) While the Office of the Speaker is Vacant:
If the office of the Speaker is vacant, the Deputy Speaker will perform the duties of the Speaker.
If the office of the Deputy Speaker is also vacant, the Governor can appoint any member of the Assembly to perform the duties of the Speaker temporarily.
(2) During the Absence of the Speaker:
When the Speaker is absent from a sitting of the Assembly, the Deputy Speaker will act as the Speaker.
If the Deputy Speaker is also absent, the rules of procedure of the Assembly will determine who will act as Speaker.
If the rules do not specify, the Assembly will decide who will temporarily take on the role of Speaker.

Article:
181. The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
 (1) At any sitting of the Legislative Assembly, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Speaker, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause ( 2 ) of Article 180 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Speaker or, as the case may be, the Deputy Speaker, is absent
 (2) The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Assembly while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the Assembly and shall, notwithstanding anything in Article 189, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an quality of votes
Title: Article 181: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker Not to Preside While a Resolution for His Removal from Office is Under Consideration
Description:
(1) Absence from Presiding During Removal Resolution:
When there is a resolution in the Legislative Assembly for the removal of the Speaker from office, the Speaker cannot preside over the proceedings during the consideration of that resolution.
Similarly, when there is a resolution for the removal of the Deputy Speaker, the Deputy Speaker cannot preside.
In both cases, though the Speaker or Deputy Speaker may be present, they must not preside over the sitting.
Clause (2) of Article 180 applies, which provides the procedure when the Speaker is absent from a sitting (in this case, the Deputy Speaker will preside or another member will be chosen temporarily).
(2) Right to Speak and Vote:
The Speaker has the right to speak in the Legislative Assembly during the consideration of the resolution for his removal.
The Speaker can also take part in the proceedings but:
He has the right to vote only once (in the first instance) on the resolution for his removal or any other matter during such proceedings.
However, the Speaker will not vote in the case of a tie (equality of votes).

Article: 182. The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council The Legislative Council of every State having such Council shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Council to be respectively Chairman and Deputy Chairman thereof and, so often as the office of Chairman or Deputy Chairman becomes vacant, the Council shall choose another member to be Chairman or Deputy Chairman, as the case may be
Title: Article 182: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council
Description: Like the Legislative Assembly, the Legislative Council must have a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman, chosen from its members.

Article:
183. Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Chairman and Deputy Chairman A member holding office as Chairman or Deputy Chairman of a Legislative Council
 (a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Council;
 (b) may at any time by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Chairman, to the Deputy Chairman, and if such member is the Deputy chairman, to the Chairman, resign his office; and
 (c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the council passed by a majority of all the then members of the Council: Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution
Title: Article 183: Vacation and Resignation of, and Removal from, the Offices of Chairman and Deputy Chairman
Description:
A member holding the office of Chairman or Deputy Chairman of a Legislary Council will vacate their office in the following situations:

(a) Ceasing to be a Member of the Council:
If the member holding the office of Chairman or Deputy Chairman stops being a member of the Legislative Council, they must vacate the office.
(b) Resignation:
A Chairman can resign by writing a resignation letter addressed to the Deputy Chairman.
A Deputy Chairman can resign by writing a resignation letter addressed to the Chairman.
(c) Removal from Office:
A Chairman or Deputy Chairman can be removed from office through a resolution passed by a majority of all the members of the Legislary Council.
However, a minimum of fourteen days' notice must be given before moving the resolution for their removal.

Article:
184. Power of the Deputy Chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman
 (1) While the office of Chairman is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Chairman or, if the office of Deputy Chairman is also vacant, by such member of the council as the Governor may appoint for the purpose
 (2) During the absence of the Chairman from any sitting of the Council the Deputy Chairman or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the Council, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the Council, shall act as Chairman
Title: Article 184: Power of the Deputy Chairman or Other Person to Perform the Duties of the Office of, or to Act as, Chairman
Description:
(1) In Case of Vacancy in the Office of Chairman:
If the office of Chairman is vacant, the duties of the office will be performed by the Deputy Chairman.
If the office of Deputy Chairman is also vacant, the Governor may appoint a member of the Council to perform the duties of the Chairman.
(2) During the Absence of the Chairman:
When the Chairman is absent from any sitting of the Council, the Deputy Chairman will perform the duties of the Chairman.
If the Deputy Chairman is also absent, a person will be chosen as per the rules of procedure of the Council to perform the duties of Chairman.
If no such person is available, then the Council itself will determine who will act as the Chairman during the absence.

Article:
185. The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
 (1) At any sitting of the Legislative Council, while any resolution for the removal of the chairman from his office is under consideration, the Chairman, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Deputy chairman, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause ( 2 ) of Article 184 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Chairman or, as the case may be, the Deputy Chairman is absent
 (2) The Chairman shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Council while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the Council and shall, notwithstanding anything in Article 189, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an equality of votes
Title: Article 185: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman Not to Preside While a Resolution for His Removal from Office is Under Consideration
Description:
(1) Presiding in the Case of Removal Resolution:
When a resolution for the removal of the Chairman from his office is being discussed, the Chairman cannot preside over the session, even if he is present.
Similarly, when a resolution for the removal of the Deputy Chairman is under consideration, the Deputy Chairman cannot preside.
In such cases, the provisions of Article 184(2) will apply, which means the duties of the Chairman will be taken over by the Deputy Chairman or another designated person, as per the rules of procedure.
(2) Right to Speak and Vote:
The Chairman has the right to speak and participate in the discussions when a removal resolution for his office is being considered.
The Chairman can vote on the resolution initially, but only during the first round of voting.
However, the Chairman is not entitled to vote in the case of a tie (equality of votes) on such a resolution or any other matter during the proceedings.

Article: 186. Salaries and allowances of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker and the Chairman and Deputy Chairman There shall be paid to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, and to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by the Legislature of the State by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule
Title: Article 186: Salaries and Allowances of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker, and the Chairman and Deputy Chairman
Description: The salaries and allowances of the Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Chairman, and Deputy Chairman are fixed by the State Legislature, or if not, they are specified in the Second Schedule of the Constitution.

Article:
187. Secretariat of State Legislature
 (1) The House or each House of the Legislature of a State shall have a separate secretarial staff: Provided that nothing in this clause shall, in the case of the Legislature of a State having a Legislative Council, be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of such Legislature
 (2) The Legislature of a State may by law regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State
 (3) Until provision is made by the Legislature of the State under clause ( 2 ), the Governor may, after consultation with the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly or the Chairman of the Legislative Council, as the case may be, make rules regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the Assembly or the Council, and any rules so made shall have effect subject to the provisions of any law made under the said clause
Title: Article 187: Secretariat of State Legislature
Description:
(1) Separate Secretarial Staff for Each House:
Each House of the State Legislature must have its own separate secretarial staff to handle its administrative tasks.
However, if the State Legislature has a Legislary Council, it is allowed to create common posts for both Houses of the Legislature.
(2) Regulation by State Legislature:
The State Legislature has the authority to pass laws regulating:
Recruitment of people to work in the secretarial staff of the House or Houses.
Conditions of service for these staff members.
(3) Interim Rules by the Governor:
Until the State Legislature passes such laws, the Governor may, after consulting with:
The Speaker of the Legislary Assembly, or
The Chairman of the Legislary Council, as applicable,
Make temporary rules that regulate the recruitment and conditions of service for secretarial staff.
These rules made by the Governor will remain in effect until the Legislature passes its own laws.

Article: 188. Oath or affirmation by members Every member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the Governor, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
Title: Article 188: Oath or Affirmation by Members
Description: Before taking their seat, every member of the Legislative Assembly or Council must take an oath or affirmation in front of the Governor or an appointed official.

Article:
189. Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum
 (1) Save as otherwise provided in this Constitution, all questions at any sitting of a House of the legislature of a State shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting, other than the Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such The Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance, but shall have and exercise a casting vote in the case of an equality of votes
 (2) A House of the Legislature of a State shall have power to act notwithstanding any vacancy in the membership thereof, and any proceedings in the legislature of a State shall be valid notwithstanding that it is discovered subsequently that some person who was not entitled so to do sat or voted or otherwise took part in the proceedings
 (3) Until the Legislature of the State by law otherwise provides, the quorum to constitute a meeting of a House of the Legislature of a State shall be ten members or one tenth of the total number of members of the House, whichever is greater
 (4) If at any time during a meeting of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative council of a State there is no quorum, it shall be the duty of the Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such, either to adjourn the House or to suspend the meeting until there is a quorum Disqualifications of Members
Title: Article 189: Voting in Houses, Power of Houses to Act Notwithstanding Vacancies and Quorum
Description:
(1) Determining Questions by Majority of Votes:
In a State Legislature, all decisions made in a House (either Legislative Assembly or Council) are decided by a majority of votes of the members present and voting.
Speakers or Chairmen (or persons acting as such) do not vote in the first instance but hold the casting vote in case of a tie (equality of votes) between members.
(2) Power to Act Despite Vacancies:
A House of the State Legislature can function and make decisions even if there are vacancies in its membership.
If it is later found that a person who was not entitled to be part of the proceedings (e.g., they were not a member) participated in the sitting, the actions of the House are still considered valid.
(3) Quorum for Meetings:
The quorum (minimum number of members required to hold a meeting) for a House to meet is determined by:
10 members, or
one-tenth of the total number of members of the House, whichever is greater.
This rule applies unless the State Legislature passes its own law to define the quorum differently.
(4) No Quorum during Meeting:
If, during a meeting of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council, there is no quorum (insufficient members to conduct business), the Speaker or Chairman (or acting person) must either:
Adjourn the meeting (postpone it to another time), or
Suspend the meeting until a quorum is present.

Article:
190. Vacation of seats
 (1) No person shall be a member of both Houses of the legislature of a State and provision shall be made by the Legislature of the State by law for the vacation by a person who is chosen a member of both Houses of his seat in one House or the other
 (2) No person shall be a member of the legislatures of two or more States specified in the First Schedule and if a person is chosen a member of the Legislatures of two or more such States, then, at the expiration of such period as may be specified in rules made by the President, that persons seat in the Legislatures of all such States shall become vacant, unless he has previously resigned his seat in the Legislatures of all but one of the States
 (3) If a member of a House of the Legislature of a State
 (a) becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause ( 1 ) or clause ( 2 ) of Article 191; or
 (b) resigns his seat by writing under his hand addressed to the Speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, and his resignation is accepted by th Speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, his seat shall thereupon becomes vacant: Provided that in the case of any resignation referred to in sub clause (b), if from information received or otherwise and after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, the Speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, is satisfied that such resignation is not voluntary or genuine, he shall not accept such resignation
 (4) If for a period of sixty days a member of a House of the Legislature of a State is without permission of the House absent from all meetings thereof, the House may declare his seat vacant: Provided that in computing the said period of sixty days no account shall be taken of any period during which the House is prorogued or is adjourned for more than four consecutive days
Title: Article 190: Vacation of Seats
Description:
(1) No Dual Membership in Both Houses of the Legislature:
A person cannot be a member of both Houses of the State Legislature (i.e., both Legislative Assembly and Legislative Council).
If someone is chosen to be a member of both Houses, the State Legislature must make provisions through law for the person to vacate their seat in one of the Houses.
(2) No Dual Membership in Legislatures of Different States:
A person cannot be a member of the Legislatures of two or more States listed in the First Schedule of the Constitution.
If a person is elected to the legislatures of multiple States, their seat in all such legislatures will become vacant after a specified period, unless the person resigns from all but one of the legislatures.
The specific time period within which the person must choose one seat is determined by rules made by the President.
(3) Disqualification and Resignation:
A seat in the House of the State Legislature will become vacant if a member:
Becomes disqualified as mentioned in Article 191, or
Resigns their seat in writing, addressed to the Speaker or Chairman, and their resignation is accepted by the Speaker/Chairman.
Resignation Validity: If the Speaker or Chairman has reason to believe that the resignation is not voluntary or genuine, they may not accept it after making necessary inquiries.
(4) Absence from House for 60 Days:
If a member of a State Legislature is absent for 60 days without permission from the House, the House may declare their seat vacant.
Exceptions: In calculating the 60-day absence, no account is taken of time when the House is prorogued or adjourned for more than four consecutive days.

Title: Article 191: Disqualifications for Membership
Description:
(1) Grounds for Disqualification:
A person will be disqualified from being chosen as a member, and from being a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State if they meet any of the following conditions:

(a) Holding an Office of Profit:

If the person holds any office of profit under the Government of India or the Government of any State listed in the First Schedule of the Constitution.
The exception to this rule is if the Legislature of the State has specifically declared the office not to disqualify its holder by law.
(b) Unsound Mind:

If the person is declared by a competent court to be of unsound mind.
(c) Undischarged Insolvent:

If the person is an undischarged insolvent (i.e., a person who has been declared bankrupt and is yet to fulfill their financial obligations).
(d) Citizenship Issues:

If the person is not a citizen of India, or has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of another country, or is under any acknowledgement of allegiance or adherence to a foreign state.
(e) Disqualification under Law:

If the person is disqualified by or under any law made by Parliament.
Explanation:

A person will not be considered to hold an office of profit simply because they are serving as a Minister for the Union or for the State, as this does not automatically lead to disqualification under this clause.
(2) Disqualification under the Tenth Schedule:
A person will also be disqualified from being a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State if they are disqualified under the provisions of the Tenth Schedule of the Constitution, which deals with defections and related disqualifications.

Article:
192. Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members
 (1) If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause ( 1 ) of Article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final
 (2) Before giving any decision on any such question, the Governor shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to such opinion
Title: Article 192: Decision on Questions as to Disqualifications of Members
Description:
(1) Reference to the Governor:
If there is any question regarding whether a member of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in Article 191(1), the question will be referred to the Governor for a decision.
The Governor's decision on the matter will be final and binding.
(2) Role of the Election Commission:
Before making any decision on the question of disqualification, the Governor must obtain the opinion of the Election Commission.
The Governor must then act in accordance with the opinion of the Election Commission.

Article: 193. Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under Article 188 or when not qualified or when disqualified If a person sits or votes as a member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State before he has complied with the requirements of Article 188, or when he knows that he is not qualified or that he is disqualified for membership thereof, or that he is prohibited from so doing by the provisions of any law made by Parliament or the legislature of the State, he shall be liable in respect of each day on which he so sits or votes to a penalty of five hundred rupees to be recovered as a debt due to the State Powers, Privileges and Immunities of State Legislatures and their Members
Title: Article 193 - Penalty for Sitting or Voting Without Being Qualified
Description: If someone sits in the legislature and votes without following proper rules (like taking the required oath, or being disqualified), they can be fined 500 rupees for each day they do this.

Article:
194. Powers, privileges, etc, of the House of Legislatures and of the members and committees thereof
 (1) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and to the rules and standing orders regulating the procedure of the Legislature, there shall be freedom of speech in the Legislature of every State
 (2) No member of the Legislature of a State shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of anything said or any vote given by him in the Legislature or any committee thereof, and no person shall be so liable in respect of the publication by or under the authority of a House of such a Legislature of any report, paper, votes or proceedings
 (3) In other respects, the powers, privileges and immunities of a House of the Legislature of a State, and of the members and the committees of a House of such Legislature, shall be such as may from time to time be defined by the Legislature by law, and, until so defined, shall be those of that House and of its members and committees immediately before the coming into force of Section 26 of the Constitution forty fourth Amendment Act, 1978
 (4) The provisions of clauses ( 1 ), ( 2 ) and ( 3 ) shall apply in relation to persons who by virtue of this Constitution have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of a House of the Legislature of a State or any committee thereof as they apply in relation to members of that Legislature
Title: Article 194: Powers, Privileges, etc., of the House of Legislatures and of the Members and Committees Thereof
Description:
(1) Freedom of Speech in the Legislature:
Every State Legislature (both Legislative Assembly and Legislative Council) is granted freedom of speech for its members during proceedings, subject to the provisions of the Constitution and the rules and standing orders governing the procedure of the Legislature.
(2) Immunity from Legal Proceedings:
Members of the Legislature of a State cannot be sued in any court for:
Anything they say in the Legislature or any of its committees.
Any vote they give in the Legislature or its committees.
The publication of any report, paper, votes, or proceedings under the authority of a House of the Legislature.
This provision ensures legal immunity for legislators in relation to their work and participation within the House.

(3) Powers, Privileges, and Immunities:
The powers, privileges, and immunities of a House of the Legislature of a State, and its members and committees, shall be defined by law as decided by the State Legislature.
Until these powers are defined by law, they will remain as they were before the 44th Amendment (1978) came into force. The exact powers will be those the House and its members had immediately before this amendment.
(4) Application to Non-Members with Rights to Speak:
The provisions of freedom of speech, immunity from legal proceedings, and powers/privileges (as mentioned in clauses 1, 2, and 3) will also apply to individuals who have the right to speak in the Legislature or its committees, even if they are not members (such as advisors or special invitees), to the same extent as they apply to members of the Legislature.

Article: 195. Salaries and allowances of members Members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of a State shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined, by the Legislature of the State by law and, until provision in that respect is so made, salaries and allowances at such rates and upon such conditions as were immediately before the commencement of the Constitution applicable in the case of members of the Legislative Assembly of the corresponding Province Legislative Procedure
Title: Article 195 - Salaries and Allowances of Members
Description: Legislators get paid for their work, and the amount they are paid is decided by the state's legislature. Until they decide, the members are paid based on the amount decided before the constitution came into force.

Article:
196. Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills
 (1) Subject to the provisions of Article 198 and 207 with respect o Money Bills and other financial Bills, a Bill may originate in either House of the Legislature of a State which has a Legislative Council
 (2) Subject to the provisions of Article 197 and 198, a Bill shall not be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of the Legislature of a State having a legislative Council unless it has been agreed to by both Houses, either without amendment or with such amendments only as are agreed to by both Houses
 (3) A Bill pending in the Legislature of a State shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the House or Houses thereof
 (4) A Bill pending in the Legislative Council of a State which has not been passed by the Legislative Assembly shall not lapse on a dissolution of the Assembly
 (5) A Bill which is pending in the Legislative Assembly of a State, or which having been passed by the Legislative Assembly is pending in the Legislative Council, shall lapse on a dissolution of the Assembly
Title: Article 196: Provisions as to Introduction and Passing of Bills
Description:
(1) Origin of Bills in Either House:
A Bill can originate in either the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State Legislature that has a Legislative Council. However, the provisions of Article 198 (Money Bills) and Article 207 (Financial Bills) still apply to Money Bills and other financial Bills.
(2) Agreement Between Both Houses for Passing a Bill:
For a Bill to be deemed passed by the Legislature of a State with a Legislative Council, it must be agreed upon by both Houses (Legislative Assembly and Legislative Council).
This agreement can be either:
Without amendment, or
With amendments that are agreed to by both Houses.
(3) Effect of Prorogation on Pending Bills:
A Bill pending in the Legislature of a State does not lapse due to the prorogation of the House or Houses. This means the Bill continues to be in process even if the House is prorogued.
(4) Effect of Dissolution of Assembly on Bills in Legislative Council:
A Bill that is pending in the Legislative Council but has not yet been passed by the Legislary Assembly will not lapse when the Legislative Assembly is dissolved.
(5) Effect of Dissolution of Assembly on Bills in Legislative Assembly and Council:
A Bill that is pending in the Legislative Assembly or that has been passed by the Legislary Assembly but is still pending in the Legislative Council will lapse when the Legislary Assembly is dissolved.

Article:
197. Restriction on powers of Legislative Council as to Bills other than Money Bills
 (1) If after a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State having a Legislative Council and transmitted to the Legislative Council
 (a) the Bill is rejected by the Council; or
 (b) more than three months elapse from the date on which the Bill is laid before the Council without the Bill being passed by it; or
 (c) the Bill is passed by the Council with amendments to which the Legislative Assembly does not agree; the Legislative Assembly may, subject to the rules regulating its procedure, pass the Bill again in the same or in any subsequent session with or without such amendments, if any, as have been made, suggested or agreed to by the Legislative Council and then transmit the Bill as so passed to the Legislative Council
 (2) If after a Bill has been so passed for the second time by the Legislative Assembly and transmitted to the Legislative Council
 (a) the Bill is rejected by the Council; or
 (b) more than one month elapses from the date on which the Bill is laid before the Council without the Bill being passed by it; or
 (c) the Bill is passed by the Council with amendments to which the Legislative Assembly does not agree; the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of the Legislature of the State in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly for the second time with such amendments, if any, as have been made or suggested by the Legislative Council and agreed to by the Legislative Assembly
 (3) Nothing in this article shall apply to a Money Bill
Title: Article 197: Restriction on Powers of Legislative Council as to Bills Other than Money Bills
Description:
This article outlines the limitations on the powers of the Legislary Council concerning non-Money Bills, after the Legislative Assembly has passed them.

(1) Powers of the Legislative Assembly After Rejection or Delay by the Legislative Council:
After a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly and sent to the Legislative Council, if any of the following occurs, the Legislative Assembly has the power to pass the Bill again in the same or subsequent sessions:
The Bill is rejected by the Legislative Council.
More than three months have passed since the Bill was sent to the Legislative Council without it being passed.
The Bill is passed by the Council with amendments that the Legislative Assembly does not agree with.
The Legislative Assembly can pass the Bill again, with or without amendments that the Council has made or suggested.
(2) Powers of the Legislative Assembly After the Second Passage:
If after the second passage of the Bill by the Legislative Assembly and transmission to the Legislary Council:
The Bill is rejected by the Council again, or
More than one month passes after the Bill is laid before the Council without the Bill being passed, or
The Bill is passed by the Council with amendments that the Legislary Assembly does not agree to,
The Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses of the Legislature of the State in the form in which it was passed by the Legislary Assembly for the second time, including any amendments the Legislary Council has suggested and the Legislary Assembly has agreed to.
(3) Exception for Money Bills:
The provisions of this article do not apply to Money Bills. Money Bills follow a separate process governed by Article 198.

Article:
198. Special procedure in respect of Money Bills
 (1) A Money Bill shall not be introduced in a Legislative Council
 (2) ) After a Money Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State having a Legislative Council, it shall be transmitted to the Legislative Council for its recommendations, and the Legislative Council shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the Legislative Assembly with its recommendations, and the Legislative Assembly may thereupon either accept or reject all or any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council
 (3) If the Legislative Assembly accepts any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses with the amendments recommended by the Legislative Council and accepted by the Legislative Assembly
 (4) If the Legislative Assembly does not accept any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly without any of the amendments recommended by the Legislative Council
 (5) If a Money Bill passed by the Legislative Assembly and transmitted to the Legislative Council for its recommendations is not returned to the Legislative Assembly within the said period of fourteen days, it shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses at the expiration of the said period in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly
Title: Article 198: Special Procedure in Respect of Money Bills
Description:
This article outlines the special procedure for dealing with Money Bills in a State Legislature with a Legislary Council.

(1) Money Bill Introduction:
A Money Bill cannot be introduced in the Legislary Council. It can only be introduced in the Legislary Assembly.
(2) Transmission to the Legislative Council:
After the Legislary Assembly passes a Money Bill, it is sent to the Legislary Council for recommendations.
The Legislary Council must return the Bill to the Legislary Assembly with its recommendations within 14 days of receiving the Bill.
(3) Acceptance of Recommendations:
If the Legislary Assembly accepts the recommendations of the Legislary Council, the Money Bill is considered passed by both Houses with the amendments agreed upon by the Assembly.
(4) Rejection of Recommendations:
If the Legislary Assembly rejects all or any of the recommendations of the Legislary Council, the Money Bill is deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly, without incorporating the recommendations.
(5) Non-return Within 14 Days:
If the Legislary Council fails to return the Money Bill with its recommendations within the 14-day period, the Money Bill is deemed to have been passed by both Houses, in the form in which it was originally passed by the Legislary Assembly.

Title: Article 199: Definition of Money Bills
Description:
This article defines what constitutes a Money Bill in the context of a State Legislature. It lays out the criteria for a Bill to be categorized as a Money Bill and outlines the procedures for determining and certifying such a Bill.

(1) Criteria for a Money Bill:
A Bill is considered a Money Bill if it deals exclusively with one or more of the following matters:

(a) Imposition, abolition, remission, alteration, or regulation of any tax.
(b) Regulation of the borrowing of money or giving any guarantee by the State, or amendments to laws relating to the State’s financial obligations.
(c) Custody of the Consolidated Fund or Contingency Fund of the State, or the payment and withdrawal of money from such Funds.
(d) Appropriation of money from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
(e) Declaring or increasing any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.
(f) Receipt of money on account of the Consolidated Fund or the Public Account of the State, or the custody or issue of such money.
(g) Any matter incidental to the above points (a) to (f).
(2) Exclusions from Money Bill Definition:
A Bill will not be considered a Money Bill solely because it involves:
The imposition of fines or pecuniary penalties.
The demand or payment of fees for licenses or services rendered.
The imposition, abolition, remission, alteration, or regulation of any tax by local authorities or bodies for local purposes.
(3) Determining a Money Bill:
If there is any dispute or question about whether a Bill introduced in a State Legislature with a Legislary Council is a Money Bill, the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly will make the final decision on the matter.
(4) Certification of Money Bill:
Every Money Bill will be endorsed with a certificate from the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, confirming that the Bill is a Money Bill:
The certificate will be included when the Money Bill is transmitted to the Legislary Council (under Article 198).
The certificate will also be included when the Money Bill is presented to the Governor for assent (under Article 200).

Article: 200. Assent to Bills When a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, has been passed by both Houses of the Legislature of the State, it shall be presented to the Governor and the Governor shall declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom or that he reserves the Bill for the consideration of the President: Provided that the Governor may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of the Bill for assent, return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill together with a message requesting that the House or Houses will reconsider the Bill or any specified provisions thereof and, in particular, will consider the desirability of introducing any such amendments as he may recommend in his message and, when a Bill is so returned, the House or Houses shall reconsider the Bill accordingly, and if the Bill is passed again by the House or Houses with or without amendment and presented to the Governor for assent, the Governor shall not withhold assent therefrom: Provided further that the Governor shall not assent to, but shall reserve for the consideration of the President, any Bill which in the opinion of the Governor would, if it became law, so derogate from the powers of the High Court as to endanger the position which that Court is by this Constitution designed to fill
Title: Article 200 - Assent to Bills
Description:
Once a Bill passes both Houses of the legislature, it goes to the Governor. The Governor can:
Approve it,
Reject it,
Send it to the President for final approval. If the Governor wants changes, they can ask the legislature to reconsider the Bill.

Article: 201. Bill reserved for consideration When a Bill is reserved by a Governor for the consideration of the President, the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom: Provided that, where the Bill is not a Money Bill, the President may direct the Governor to return the Bill to the House or, as the case may be, the Houses of the Legislature of the State together with such a message as it mentioned in the first proviso to Article 200 and, when a Bill is so returned, the House or Houses shall reconsider it accordingly within a period of six months from the date of receipt of such message and, if it is again passed by the House or Houses with or without amendment, it shall be presented again to the President for his consideration Procedure in Financial Matters
Title: Article 201 - Bill Reserved for Consideration
Description: If the Governor sends a Bill to the President, the President decides whether to approve it or not. If the Bill isn't about money, the President can send it back to the legislature for more work.

Title: Article 202: Annual Financial Statement
Description:
This article outlines the process and requirements for presenting the Annual Financial Statement of a State in India. It specifies the procedures and contents of the financial statement, as well as the types of expenditure that are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.

(1) Presentation of the Annual Financial Statement:
The Governor of the State is required to lay before the House or Houses of the State Legislature a statement for each financial year.
This statement is known as the Annual Financial Statement, and it presents the estimated receipts and expenditure for the coming year.
(2) Breakdown of Expenditure Estimates:
The estimates of expenditure in the Annual Financial Statement must be shown separately in two categories:
(a) Expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of the State (as specified in the Constitution).
(b) Other expenditure to be made from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
Additionally, the statement must distinguish between:
Expenditure on revenue account (regular, recurring expenses).
Other expenditure (capital, non-recurring expenses).
(3) Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State:
The following items are considered expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State:

(a) The emoluments (salaries and allowances) of the Governor and other related expenditure for the Governor’s office.
(b) The salaries and allowances of:
The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
In States with a Legislary Council, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislary Council.
(c) Debt charges, which include:
Interest, sinking fund charges, and redemption charges for loans.
Other expenses related to the raising of loans, as well as the service and redemption of debt.
(d) The salaries and allowances of Judges of any High Court.
(e) Any sums required to satisfy judgments, decrees, or awards from any court or arbitral tribunal.
(f) Any other expenditure declared by the Constitution or the State Legislature (through law) as charged on the Consolidated Fund.

Article:
203. Procedure in Legislature with respect to estimates
 (1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of a State shall not be submitted to the vote of the Legislative Assembly, but nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in the Legislature of any of those estimates
 (2) So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants to the Legislative Assembly, and the Legislative Assembly shall have power to assent, or to refuse to assent, to any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein
 (3) No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the Governor
Title: Article 203: Procedure in Legislature with Respect to Estimates
Description:
This article outlines the procedure that must be followed in the Legislature of a State regarding the estimates of expenditure as part of the Annual Financial Statement. It focuses on how the Legislative Assembly handles these estimates, including the process of discussing and approving expenditure.

(1) Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund:
The part of the expenditure estimates that is charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State (as specified under Article 202) shall not be submitted to the vote of the Legislative Assembly.
However, this does not prevent the Legislature from discussing these charged expenditures. The discussion can still take place in the legislative process.
(2) Other Expenditures (Demands for Grants):
The estimates related to other expenditures (i.e., those not charged on the Consolidated Fund) are submitted to the Legislative Assembly in the form of demands for grants.
The Legislative Assembly has the power to:
Assent to any demand for a grant (approve it).
Refuse to assent to any demand (reject it).
Reduce the amount specified in any demand for a grant.
(3) Recommendation of the Governor:
A demand for a grant can only be made on the recommendation of the Governor.
This means that the Governor must formally recommend the grant before the Legislative Assembly can consider it.

Article:
204. Appropriation Bills
 (1) As soon as may be after the grants under article 203 have been made by the Assembly, there shall be introduced a Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of all moneys required to meet
 (a) the grants so made by the assembly; and
 (b) the expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State but not exceeding in any case the amount shown in the statement previously laid before the House or Houses
 (2) No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in the House or either House of the Legislature of the State which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made or of varying the amount of any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State, and the decision of the person presiding as to whether an amendment is inadmissible under this clause shall be final
 (3) Subject to the provisions of articles 205 and 206, no money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of the State except under appropriation made by law passed in accordance with the provisions of this article
Title: Article 204: Appropriation Bills
Description:
This article deals with the process for appropriating funds from the Consolidated Fund of the State to meet the expenditures approved by the Legislative Assembly.

(1) Introduction of Appropriation Bill:
After the grants are made by the Legislative Assembly (as per Article 203), an Appropriation Bill must be introduced.
This Bill is introduced to appropriation (i.e., allocate) the money needed for:
(a) The grants made by the Assembly.
(b) The expenditure that is charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.
The total amount for this appropriation cannot exceed the amount shown in the financial statement (as laid out earlier in the procedure).
(2) Restrictions on Amendments to the Appropriation Bill:
No amendments can be proposed to change:
The amount or the destination of any grant made by the Legislative Assembly.
The amount of any expenditure that is charged on the Consolidated Fund.
The presiding officer (Speaker or Chairman) of the House has the authority to decide whether an amendment is admissible. Their decision on this matter is final.
(3) Money Withdrawals from the Consolidated Fund:
No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of the State unless it is done according to an appropriation made by law. This appropriation must follow the procedure described in this article, i.e., it must be authorized by a law passed in accordance with Article 204.

Article:
205. Supplementary, additional or excess grants
 (1) The Governor shall
 (a) if the amount authorised by any law made in accordance with the provisions of article 204 to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is found to be insufficient for the purposes of that year or when a need has arisen during the current financial year for supplementary or additional expenditure upon some new service not contemplated in the annual financial statement for that year, or
 (b) if any money has been spent on any service during a financial year in excess of the amount granted for that service and for that year, cause to be laid before the House or the Houses of the Legislature of the State another statement showing the estimated amount of that expenditure or cause to be presented to the Legislative Assembly of the State a demand for such excess, as the case may be
 (2) The provisions of articles 202, 203 and 204 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure or demand and also to any law to be made authorising the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of the State to meet such expenditure or the grant in respect of such demand as they have effect in relation to the annual financial statement and the expenditure mentioned therein or to a demand for a grant and the law to be made for the authorisation of appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of the State to meet such expenditure or grant
Title: Article 205: Supplementary, Additional, or Excess Grants
Description:
This article addresses situations where the initial financial provisions made for a particular financial year need adjustments during the year.

(1) Governor's Role in Supplementary Grants:
The Governor must take action in the following cases:

(a) Insufficient funds for a particular service:
If the money allocated for a specific service during the current financial year is found to be insufficient for its purpose.
If there is a new need for expenditure on services that were not planned or not included in the annual financial statement.
(b) Excess expenditure:
If money has already been spent on a service that exceeds the amount originally granted for that service in the current year.
In either case, the Governor must:

Present a statement showing the estimated amount of expenditure or
Present a demand for the excess amount to the Legislative Assembly for approval.
